* Half-metallic ferromagnets with high Curie temperatures are ideal for spintronics applications.
* Experimental and theoretical efforts have been devoted to designing and searching for such materials, with particular attention given to Cr-doped dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMS) or Cr-based alloys, specifically CrAs and CrSb in zinc blende (zb) structure.
* Akinaga et al. were able to grow zb thin films of CrAs on GaAs (001) substrates, which showed ferromagnetic behavior at temperatures in excess of 400 k and magnetic moments of 3@xmath2 per CrAs unit.
* The half-metallic character of CrAs has been verified by theoretical calculations, and the high Curie temperature has been supported by some studies.
* Thin films of CrSb grown by solid-source molecular beam epitaxy on GaAs, (Al,Ga)As, and GaSb have been found to be of zb structure and ferromagnetic with Tc higher than 400 k.
* Galanakis and Mavropoulos examined the possibility of half-metallic behavior in ordered zb compounds of transition metals V, Cr, and Mn with p, As, Sb, S, Se, and Te elements. Their theoretical study shows that the half-metallic ferromagnetic character of these compounds is preserved over a wide range of lattice parameters.
* Yamana studied the effects of tetragonal distortion on zb CrAs and CrSb and found the half-metallicity to survive large tetragonal distortions.
* Zhao and Zunger argued that zb MnAs, CrAs, CrSb, and CrTe are epitaxially unstable against the NiAs structure, and zb CrSe is epitaxially stable only for lattice constants higher than 6.2, remaining half-metallic at such volumes.
* Theoretical studies on the exchange interaction, Curie temperature, and their volume dependence for Cr-based alloys are limited, and the mixed pnictide-chalcogenide systems offer the possibility of creating these alloys over a larger range of the lattice parameter with a larger variation in the exchange interactions.

• The complex scaling (dilatation) method is used to reveal a resonance state by the appearance of an isolated complex eigenvalue on the spectrum of the non-Hermitian complex scaled Hamiltonian. However, the rotation angle must be large enough to rotate the continuum part of the spectrum beyond the resonance's complex eigenvalue. The complex virial theorem and graphical methods are used to pick the best numerical solution of a given problem.

• The density of states (DOS) method is used to obtain the energy and lifetime of the resonance in a simple way, both quantities are obtained as least square fitting parameters. The availability of the DOS allows for the calculation of resonance-state energies without answering the question about the convergence properties of eigenvalues in the continuum when the size of the Hamiltonian matrix changes. However, there is no single procedure to assess the accuracy of the numerical findings and its convergence properties, or which values to pick between the several "candidates" that the method offers.

• The theme of parity-time symmetric systems was introduced as an alternative to standard quantum theory, where non-hermitian Hamiltonians can still give rise to real spectra. This concept has been experimentally realized in optical waveguiding arrays with controlled gain and loss.

• The paper proposes the construction of 2D plaquettes as fundamental building blocks for 2D lattices with parity-time symmetry. Four basic types of plaquettes are introduced, three of which are four-site squares and the fourth is a five-site cross. These plaquettes are inspired by earlier works on 2D hamiltonian lattices and can be accessed with current experimental techniques.

• The stability of stationary states supported by the plaquettes is examined against small perturbations, and it is found that many effects, such as the termination of solution branches at critical points and the breaking of parity-time symmetry, can occur. The spectral stability of different configurations is also examined, with most stationary modes being unstable.
</summary>

- The family of iron pnictides is an important prototype system for unconventional high-temperature superconductivity, with various sub-families and a wide structural variety. They share common physical properties such as magnetic behavior and a phase transition from tetragonal to orthorhombic crystal symmetry, often accompanied by antiferromagnetic order.
- The suppression of these phase transitions is believed to be crucial for the emergence of superconductivity. Understanding the magnetic fluctuations in the iron pnictides is mandatory to unveil the physics underlying the superconductivity, but it has proven to be more complex than anticipated. There is ongoing debate about whether the magnetic moments are better described by an itinerant or localized model, and the role of correlation effects is still not clear.
- Angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) is an essential experimental tool for studying the electronic structure of iron pnictides. However, DFT calculations often have problems reproducing all features of ARPES spectra correctly, which is often attributed to strong correlation effects. Additionally, the connection between the magnetic phase of the iron pnictides and the resulting consequences for ARPES is often ignored, leading to mixed magnetic domains and lost information on anisotropy.
- Experimentally, it is possible to effectively detwin the crystals by applying uniaxial stress during the measurement, but such measurements are connected with several technical difficulties. Understanding the electronic properties of iron pnictide superconductors comprehensively and gaining deeper insights into the influence of in-plane anisotropy in the magnetic phase requires these studies.
- The work presents a comprehensive DFT study on the magnetic phase of a specific iron pnictide and its corresponding ARPES spectra. The computational results can be directly compared to available experimental ARPES data on detwinned crystals. The Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker-Green Function (KKR-GF) approach is used, which has been shown to be accurate for dealing with iron pnictides. The impact of disorder due to substitution is dealt with by the coherent potential approximation (CPA), giving reliable results.

• The No-Core Shell Model/Resonating Group Method (NCSM/RGM) is a microscopic cluster approach for treating both structure and reactions in light nuclear systems. It combines a microscopic cluster technique with realistic interactions and a consistent description of nucleon clusters.
• The NCSM/RGM has been successful in studying two-body cluster systems, but its extension to three-body cluster states is essential for the study of nuclear systems with such configurations.
• Three-body cluster configurations have been introduced into the NCSM/RGM, and preliminary results for the ground state and continuum states of 1he within a 2he+n+n basis have been presented.
• The NCSM/RGM approach for three-body cluster systems involves expanding the many-body wave function over a basis of three-body cluster channel states built from the NCSM wave function of each of the three clusters.
• The microscopic R-matrix method on a Lagrange mesh is used to solve the Schrödinger equations for three-cluster systems.
• The NCSM/RGM approach has been applied to the study of 1he, the lightest borromean nucleus, and similarity-renormalization-group evolved potentials obtained from the chiral NN interaction have been used in the calculations.

</summary>

* XB158 exhibited strong intensity modulation on a 10017@xmath050 s period during the 2002 January XMM-Newton observation and similar variation in folded lightcurves from 1991 June ROSAT and 2000 June XMM-Newton observations.
* The amplitude of modulation decreased with increasing source intensity and was not present in the 2001 June XMM-Newton observation, indicating a probable neutron star binary with a low mass donor and a separation of 10@xmath510@xmath6 cm.

* The preparation of thin films of MnSi on silicon substrates has shown promising prospects for future spintronic devices, as they offer a variety of magnetic phases and are easy to integrate into devices due to the use of silicon as a substrate material. The benefit of thin films is the existence of the skyrmion phase in an extended region of the magnetic phase diagram due to uniaxial anisotropy. However, the drawback is the low magnetic ordering temperature, which is below the liquid nitrogen temperature.
* A suitable candidate for compounds with similar spin order at higher temperatures is MnGe, which has a magnetic ordering temperature of 170K and a helical spin structure. A large topological Hall effect, attributed to a skyrmion phase, was observed in MnGe, and small angle neutron scattering experiments provided further evidence for the existence of skyrmions. The synthesis of MnGe is laborious, but molecular beam epitaxy allows for thin film growth under strong non-equilibrium conditions. A seedlayer of MnSi can be used to prepare a b20 crystal structure for MnGe growth on Si(111) substrates, as the lattice constant of MnGe within the (111) plane matches that of Si with a misfit of only 2%.

Note: I have summarized the main points regarding the preparation and potential applications of MnSi and MnGe thin films for spintronic devices and their magnetic properties.

- Hu Aqr, a cataclysmic variable, is composed of a white dwarf and a main-sequence companion star, with two planets orbiting the system.
- The two planets were discovered through irregularities in observed-calculated variations, and were found to have a 5.7 and 7.6 mass, in eccentric orbits with periods of 2.8 and 12.8 days.
- The two-planet configuration is dynamically unstable, but a small fraction of numerical simulations show long-term stability.
- The presence of the inner planet allows for the degeneracy between the donor mass, radius, and core mass at the moment of Roche-lobe overflow to be broken, providing information about the rate of mass loss in the common-envelope phase.
- The outer planet validates this calculation and determines the conditions under which the CV was born.
- The observed white dwarf mass provides an upper limit to the mass of the core of the primary star at the moment of Roche-lobe contact, and therefore also provides a minimum to the companion mass.
- The evolution of the radius of the donor star as a function of core mass is calculated using the Henyey stellar evolution code MESA and the AMUSE framework, which allows for the calculation of the orbital separation at the moment of Roche-lobe overflow.

* The detection of X-ray, optical, and radio afterglows from gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) suggests that they are of cosmological origin, with the "fireball model" being strongly favored. However, the puzzle of GRBs is far from being resolved, with a major problem being the uncertainty in whether they are due to highly collimated jets or isotropic fireballs, which affects the determination of their energetics.
* Three methods may help determine the degree of beaming in GRBs: (1) based on analytic solutions, the break in the light curve of optical afterglows from a jetted GRB should occur during the relativistic phase, but this method is not conclusive due to the smoothness of the break and other factors; (2) optical afterglows from a jet can be strongly polarized, but polarization can only be observed under certain conditions; and (3) due to relativistic beaming effects, the majority of jetted GRBs cannot be observed, but their corresponding late-time afterglow emission can safely reach us, which could allow measurement of the GRB collimation angle.
* The absence of large numbers of orphan afterglows in many surveys has been regarded as evidence that the collimation cannot be extreme, but recently, it has been argued that measurement of the GRB beaming angle using optical orphan searches is extremely difficult due to the low optical flux density when the afterglow emission from a jet begins to go into a much larger solid angle than the initial burst. Additionally, there should be many "failed gamma-ray bursts" (fGRBs) that cannot be observed in gamma-rays but have detectable long-lasting afterglows, which will also manifest themselves as orphan afterglows.

• Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are elusive events in the universe that last for less than a minute and produce X-ray afterglows that can be detected for several hours or days after the burst.
• BEPPOSAX, ASCA, and Chandra satellites have observed more than a few X-ray afterglows in the last five years.
• GRB 011211 was detected and localized by BEPPOSAX WFC1 on December 11, 2001, and was found to have a long duration and faintness both in X- and @xmath0-rays.
• An optical afterglow of GRB 011211 was discovered by Grav et al. (2001) and was found to have an absorption line system corresponding to a redshift of z=2.14.
• GRB 001025 was detected by the RXTE All-Sky Monitor on October 25, 2000, and had a peak 5-12 keV flux of @xmath154 crab. Its optical afterglow has never been detected.
• XMM-Newton observed the location of GRB 001025 starting @xmath151.9 days after the burst and detected two X-ray sources in the error box.
• The spectrum of the brighter source can be approximated by a power-law with a photon index of @xmath5=2.01@xmath60.09 and galactic absorption value n@xmath31=6@xmath2210@xmath32 @xmath2.

* The paper discusses the Generalized Petersen Graphs (GPGs), which are a class of graphs introduced by Coxeter and later studied by Watkins. The paper focuses on studying the independence number of GPGs, which is the size of the largest independent set in a graph. The independence number is an NP-hard problem, and the paper aims to find upper and lower bounds for special classes of graphs, specifically for GPGs. The paper also explores the relationship between the independence number and other graph parameters, such as vertex cover and domination number.
* The paper proves several results related to the independence number of GPGs. For instance, it shows that if both the parameters n and k are odd, then the independence number is equal to n/2. It also proves that if n is even and k is odd, then the independence number is at most n/2. The paper also provides some exact values for the independence number for specific pairs of n and k. Additionally, the paper discusses the relationship between the independence number and the treewidth of a graph and shows that for fixed k, the independence number of GPGs can be found in linear time.

• Ai3, a layered organic material, has recently regained interest due to the discovery of low-energy massless Dirac fermions under hydrostatic pressure.
• Ai3 is different from graphene and topological insulators in several ways, including tilted Dirac cones, anisotropic Fermi surface, smaller average Fermi velocity, and the presence of additional massive carriers near the Fermi level.
• The effective coupling constant for Coulomb-type electron-electron interactions is expected to be ten times larger in ai3 than in graphene, indicating the relevance of electronic correlations.
• Magneto-transport measurements under hydrostatic pressure larger than 3 GPa show the existence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes, with scattering mechanisms due to strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers.
• The carrier densities and mobilities are extracted from the magneto-conductivity curves, revealing a strong temperature dependence and a topological merging of Dirac points at high but experimentally accessible pressure.
• The temperature dependence of the carrier densities is discussed in comparison with the model of massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers, with thermopower measurements corroborating the two-carrier scenario.
• The effective mass of the massive carriers is extracted from the equation for massive carriers, while the Fermi velocity of the Dirac carriers is extracted from the equation for Dirac carriers.
• The analysis of the data is based on the study of the magneto-conductivity and is similar to the one presented in ref. for multi-carrier semiconductor systems.

</summary>

<summary>

• Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) is often said to be unconditionally secure, but it requires the users' devices to meet certain requirements for the security to hold.

• In practice, it is difficult for devices to meet these requirements, leading to the possibility of attacks on QKD systems. Some attacks have been successfully demonstrated against practical QKD systems.

• To combat these attacks, countermeasures such as device-independent security proofs and experimental measures have been proposed.

• A new scheme called Measurement Device Independent QKD (MDIQKD) has been proposed, which removes potential loopholes in detector measurements without sacrificing performance.

• MDIQKD has been shown to cover twice the distance of standard decoyed QKD, and only requires the assumption that the preparation of quantum signal sources by the users is nearly perfect.

• The characterization of the signal source is easier than that of the detection unit, and with MDIQKD, researchers can focus on imperfections of signal sources rather than detectors.

• One important imperfection of the sources is the basis-dependent flaw, which decreases the achievable distance in standard BB84. The security of MDIQKD under this imperfection needs to be investigated.
</summary>

• The paper discusses the core entropy function, which is a continuous function that extends to the Mandelbrot set. This answers a question posed by W. Thurston about the core entropy of polynomials. The core entropy function can be defined purely combinatorially and displays a rich fractal structure that reflects the underlying geometry of the Mandelbrot set. The concept of core entropy generalizes the entropy theory of real quadratic maps to complex polynomials.

• The core entropy function is used to study the parameter space of polynomials. For instance, the restriction of the core entropy function to non-real veins of the Mandelbrot set is monotone, which implies that the lamination for the Mandelbrot set can be reconstructed by looking at level sets of the core entropy function. The value of the core entropy function is equal, up to a constant factor, to the Hausdorff dimension of the set of biaccessible angles for a polynomial. For dendritic Julia sets, the core entropy also equals the asymptotic stretch factor of a polynomial as a rational map.

• The paper describes an algorithm, devised by Thurston, that considers a larger matrix whose entries are pairs of postcritical angles to compute the entropy of a polynomial. This algorithm does not require knowledge of the topology of the hubbard tree. The algorithm is then used to prove that the entropy function is continuous. The algorithm is also used to prove that the entropy function is Hölder continuous at angles where the core entropy function is not Hölder continuous.

• The paper also develops combinatorial tools to deal with growth rates of countable graphs. These tools are used to prove that the inverse of the growth rate of a graph equals the smallest real positive root of a holomorphic function constructed by counting the multi-cycles in the graph. The paper also defines a labeled wedge, which is a combinatorial object that consists of pairs of integers that can be labeled as separated or non-separated. The paper then associates an infinite graph to each labeled wedge and proves that it has bounded cycles, which allows us to apply the theory developed in the first part of the paper. The paper then applies these combinatorial techniques to the core entropy and proves that the growth rate of the graph associated to a labeled wedge varies continuously as a function of the external angle. * Fe-based superconductors (FEBS) are a non-cuprate class of high-temperature superconductors with an unconventional superconducting state, the origin of which is still debated.
* FEBS can be divided into two subclasses: pnictides and chalcogenides, both with a square lattice of iron as the basic element.
* The Fermi surface (FS) in FEBS is formed by Fe-orbitals and consists of two hole sheets around the @xmath11 point and two electron sheets around the @xmath12 and @xmath13 points in the two-dimensional Brillouin zone.
* Nesting between these two groups of sheets leads to enhanced antiferromagnetic fluctuations, which can result in different superconducting gap symmetries and structures.
* The Random-Phase Approximation Spin Fluctuation (RPA-SF) approach suggests that the extended s-wave gap that changes sign between hole and electron FS sheets is the main instability for a wide range of doping concentrations.
* Inelastic neutron scattering (INS) is a useful tool for probing the gap structure, as the measured dynamical spin susceptibility in the superconducting state carries information about the gap structure.
* A well-defined peak in neutron spectra has been reported in 1111, 122, and 11 systems, which is commonly explained as the spin resonance appearing due to the s± state.
* However, recent ARPES and Andreev spectroscopy results suggest that there are at least two distinct gaps present in 11, 122, and 1111 systems, and even three gaps in LiFeAs, which raises questions about the spin resonance frequency in systems with multiple gaps.

</summary>

<summary>

• Massive stars play a crucial role in shaping the energy flow and material cycles in galaxies, but their formation process remains unclear.
• Recent high-resolution observations, enabled by advances in instrumentation, have revealed the environment surrounding individual massive protostellar systems. These observations suggest that massive stars may form via accretion, similar to low-mass stars.
• Further discrimination between competing models of massive star formation can be achieved by studying the properties, particularly the young stellar populations, of hot molecular cores in the mid-infrared (7-25 μm) window.
• Class II methanol masers are found to exclusively trace regions of massive star formation and are generally not associated or are offset from UCHII regions.
• High-spatial-resolution observations of three star-forming complexes traced by methanol maser emission have uncovered the embedded sources inside the cores at mid-infrared wavelengths, revealing multiple point sources at close angular separations.
• Monte Carlo simulations suggest that it is difficult to generate the observed mass distributions of the most massive stars in the cores using a standard form of the initial mass function (IMF), implying that the mass distribution of the most massive stars may not be produced by sampling a standard form of the IMF from the reservoir of gas available for star formation.

</summary>

- The first evidence of time reversal symmetry violation was found in the kaon system, and it is now a crucial area of study in the search for physics beyond the Standard Model. Various theories beyond the Standard Model, such as grand unified theories and supersymmetric theories, imply specific ways of time reversal symmetry violation. However, relating hadronic degrees of freedom to quark degrees of freedom is challenging due to the absence of a complete solution of quantum chromodynamics at the energies considered.
- The paper provides estimates on hadronic matrix elements that arise when relating quark operators to the effective hadronic parameterizations of the time reversal symmetry violating interaction. The charge exchange and axial vector type exchange nucleon nucleon interaction are considered, and the ansatz to calculate matrix elements from the quark structure is described. The results for different types of quark models are presented, and the importance of experimental precision tests in translating experimental constraints to a more fundamental interaction level is emphasized.

</summary>

• The text discusses the use of modified theories of gravity to explain the accelerated expansion of the universe. The authors focus on the Lovelock theory of gravity and the Gauss-Bonnet invariant, which is a quadratic curvature invariant that is a topological term in 4-dimensions. They also discuss the coupling between matter Lagrangian and the Gauss-Bonnet invariant, which leads to non-conservation of the energy-momentum tensor and the appearance of an extra force that causes massive test particles to follow non-geodesic trajectories.

• The text also explores the reconstruction technique, which involves using known cosmic solutions in the modified field equations to find the corresponding function that reproduces the given evolutionary cosmic history. The authors apply this technique to the Lovelock theory of gravity and the Gauss-Bonnet invariant gravity, and they discuss the stability of power-law solutions in these theories.

• The authors also discuss the stability of de Sitter solutions in the context of the Lovelock theory of gravity and the Gauss-Bonnet invariant gravity. They use numerical techniques to solve the perturbed equations for specific models and find that some models are stable against linear perturbations while others are unstable.
</summary>

<summary>

- Majorana fermions (MFs) are real solutions of the Dirac equation and are their own antiparticles. They were originally proposed as a model for neutrinos but have recently been predicted to occur as quasiparticle bound states in engineered condensed matter systems.
* MFs obey non-Abelian statistics, which is important for realizing potential applications in decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing.
* The possibility of hosting MFs in exotic solid-state systems has focused on topological superconductors, and various platforms including topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains have been proposed to support Majorana states based on the superconducting proximity effect.
* Experimentally observing the unique Majorana signatures is still a challenging task, and most experimental evidence for Majorana bound states relies on measurements of tunneling conductance.
* An all-optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs using quantum dots (QDs) and nanomechanical resonators (NRS) in a hybrid system with an optical pump-probe scheme.
* The proposed scheme can provide a new platform for robust manipulation of MFs and MFs-based quantum information processing.
</summary>

<summary>

* Impurities can significantly alter the properties of a quantum system's spectrum, affecting its coherence and transport properties.
* In the absence of interactions and with random impurity distribution, all states are exponentially localized in 1D and 2D, while a mobility edge exists in 3D. Correlated impurity positions can lead to the appearance of delocalized states in the spectrum.
* The effects of correlated disorder have been studied in 1D, but exploration in 2D is limited to speckle potentials and pseudo-2D random dimer lattices. Correlations in speckle potentials can mimic the presence of a mobility edge, but all states are localized in the thermodynamic limit.
* Random dimers introduce delocalized states in pseudo-2D lattices, with a main statistical difference being the decay of the correlation function, which is algebraic for the first and exponential for the second.
* A short-range correlated disorder in a weakly interacting Bose gas confined on a 2D square lattice can lead to a richness of phenomena, such as modifying the condensate and superfluid fraction, shifting the onset of superfluidity, and inducing exotic phases like the Bose glass.
* A 2D generalization of the dual random dimer model (2D-DRDM) has been introduced, where impurities cannot be first neighbors and each impurity modifies the hopping with its nearest neighbor sites. In the non-interacting regime, there exists a resonance energy at which the impurity is transparent, leading to delocalized states around this energy.
* The 2D-DRDM resonance energy does not depend on the system dimensionality and is the same as in 1D. In the presence of weak interactions, the 2D-DRDM drives the homogeneity of the ground state, inducing a non-monotonic behavior of the condensate spatial delocalization and condensate fraction as a function of disorder strength.
* The dependence of these quantities on interaction strength can be explained by including the effect of the healing length in the resonance condition discussion.
* The tight-binding single-particle Hamiltonian is considered, focusing on a 2D square lattice with on-site energies, hopping terms, and impurities

• Quantum entanglement is a physical resource with conservation laws, and can be characterized and manipulated independently of its physical realization. It is useful in making quantitative predictions and is regarded as a physical resource.
• The entanglement of formation and the entanglement of distillation are two measures of entanglement that satisfy the requirements for a physical entanglement measure. They give the value zero for certain states, which might be counterintuitive, but is unavoidable due to the inherent uncertainty surrounding a mixed state.
• The problem of bipartite entanglement for an open system is one of tripartite entanglement for the system and environment, and is complicated by the fact that the state of the environment is complex and unknown. To fully characterize the entanglement in this situation, the inherent uncertainty of the mixed state description must be removed.
• Quantum trajectory unravelings of open system dynamics can be used to measure entanglement in a more complete way by considering the way in which information about the system is read from the environment. This approach yields a contextual entanglement measure that is dependent on the kind of measurements made.

</summary>

• The code in question is a stellar oscillation code designed for computing adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models, with a focus on accuracy and flexibility in integration method and frequency determination. It was inspired by the review and tests of adiabatic stellar oscillations provided by @xcite.

• The code defines the equilibrium model in terms of a minimal set of dimensionless variables, as well as mass, radius, and other physical properties. It also introduces a new set of dependent variables for numerical integration, which allows for the calculation of modes of arbitrarily high degree in a complete model. The code can handle both complete stellar models and envelope models, with appropriate boundary conditions at the center and surface of the star.

• The code uses a shooting method or a relaxation technique to solve the equations of adiabatic stellar oscillations, with the option for Richardson extrapolation to improve the precision of the computed frequencies. The code also includes techniques for redistributing the mesh in a way that takes into account the asymptotic behavior of the eigenfunctions, as well as options for outputting eigenfunctions and mode inertia.

• The code has been used in a number of studies and comparisons with other oscillation codes, and has been improved with the installation of a fourth-order integration scheme and the implementation of a new classification scheme for dipolar modes of low order in centrally condensed models. The code is currently being extended to cover second-order effects of rotation and integrated with the astec evolution code for full calculation of oscillation frequencies.

<summary>

* Continuous variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) has seen advancements in theoretical analysis and experimental implementation, with practical systems such as fiber-based Gaussian-modulated and discrete-modulated coherent-state protocol QKD systems demonstrated over tens of kilometers. The unconditional security of these systems has been confirmed through security analysis of the equivalent entanglement-based (EB) scheme.
* However, traditional security analysis of the EB scheme in CVQKD only considers the signal beam and not the local oscillator (LO), an auxiliary light beam used for phase reference and balanced homodyne detection. This leaves security loopholes as LO is within Eve's manipulating domain. The necessity of monitoring LO intensity for security proofs in discrete QKD protocols embedded in continuous variables has been discussed, and the excess noise caused by imperfect subtraction of balanced homodyne detectors in the presence of LO intensity fluctuations has been noted and quantified.
* In practical CVQKD implementation, shot noise scaling with LO power measured before key distribution is assumed constant, with pulses having large LO intensity fluctuations discarded. This approach gives Eve an advantage in exploiting LO intensity fluctuations. A paper proposes an attacking scheme based on this fluctuation and analyzes the effect on the secret key rate with and without LO monitoring for reverse and direct reconciliation protocols.
* The paper finds that LO intensity fluctuation could compromise secret keys severely if not properly addressed. It emphasizes the importance of accurate LO intensity monitoring to ensure the security of CVQKD practical implementation.

</summary>

• Highly structured Hi distribution, including cavities, shells, and supershells, is a manifestation of activity inside gas-rich galaxies.
• Such features were first discovered in the Milky Way and are now known to exist in various spiral galaxies.
• Exceptionally huge Hi arcs and loops have been identified in edge-on spirals, interpreted as expanding supershells due to their loop-like appearance and velocity range.
• Supershells can be attributed to internal or external sources: internal sources involve starbursts, stellar winds, and supernova explosions, while external sources suggest infall of massive gas clouds onto the galactic plane.
• The main difficulty with the starburst model lies in the required input energies for the largest shells, often needing staggering numbers of supernova events.
• Alternative explanations propose that Hi supershells are produced by gamma-ray bursts or infall of massive gas clouds.
• Recent observations reveal galaxies with extremely large Hi supershells but no evidence of interaction or nearby companions, suggesting a new explanation for their formation.
• The proposed model suggests that Hi supershells are formed by radio jets plowing through the interstellar medium, accreting gas, and inflating bubbles, providing an internal energy source and resolving the energy problem.

<summary>

• Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are characterized by no hydrogen but strong silicon lines in their spectra at maximum brightness, and are used as standard candles to measure distances to remote galaxies due to their uniform light curves and high luminosity.

• The accreting white dwarf (WD) model is a plausible explosion model for SNe Ia, where a WD in a binary system accretes material from a companion star, increasing its mass until it reaches the Chandrasekhar mass limit and explodes.

• Recent progress in the accreting WD model includes the introduction of a stellar wind from the WD, which helps sustain stable mass transfer in the progenitor systems of SNe Ia. There are two main evolutionary paths leading to SNe Ia: the super soft X-ray source (SSS) channel and the symbiotic channel.

• The companion stars leading to SNe Ia can be predicted by the accreting WD model, but this evolutionary scenario has not been confirmed by observations. Identifying the companion star that should remain in the vicinity of the explosion site is required for confirmation.

• Observations of a G2IV star (Tycho G) near the Tycho supernova remnant (SNR) suggest that it may be the companion star of the SNR, but this hypothesis is still debated. The presence of broad wings in Fe II absorption lines in the UV spectrum of a star behind the SNR ejecta can be used to identify companion stars of SNe Ia.

• The amount of Fe I in the ejecta of Tycho SNR has been estimated, and spectra of a star located at the center of a SNR have been calculated to discuss whether Fe I absorption lines can be identified in the spectrum of the companion star.

• The presence of absorption lines with broad blue wings in the spectrum of a star inside the ejecta of a SNR can indicate that the star is the companion star, but there are factors that might reduce or erase these distinct absorption features.

• The theory of phase transitions was formulated by Landau and later refined using the renormalization group. Order parameters are used to identify phases.
• In some systems, order parameters can be challenging to define, as seen in topological states like topological insulators, quantum spin Hall states, or quantum spin liquids.
• Machine learning techniques, particularly unsupervised learning algorithms, have shown promise in identifying order parameters and phase transitions.
• Variational autoencoders, a modern version of autoencoders, impose constraints on encoded representations, transforming the algorithm into a latent variable model for its input data.
• A study demonstrates the use of unsupervised learning to determine phase transitions in physical systems without any information about the microscopic theory or the order parameter.
• The algorithms are able to find a low-dimensional latent representation of the physical system, which coincides with the correct order parameter, and the reconstruction error can be used as a universal identifier for phase transitions.

* Baade's first color-magnitude diagrams (CMDs) for dwarf spheroidal (dSph) companions of the Milky Way, including the Draco system, showed they are essentially pure population II systems, similar to globular clusters, based on the presence of RR Lyrae stars and the features present in their CMDs.
* However, Baade noted that there are characteristics in the stellar populations of dSph galaxies that differentiate them from globular clusters, such as extreme red horizontal branches and distinct characteristics of variable stars.
* The discovery of carbon stars in dSph galaxies led to the recognition that these differences are due to the presence of an intermediate-age population.
* The CMDs of several dSph galaxies, such as Carina, Fornax, Leo I, and others, show evidence of an intermediate-age population, while some dSph galaxies, like Ursa Minor, only show a dominant old stellar population.
* An old stellar population, traced by a horizontal branch (HB), has been observed in all dSph galaxies satellites of the Milky Way, except Leo I, regardless of their subsequent star formation histories.
* Leo I is peculiar in that it lacks a conspicuous old population and has a much larger fraction of intermediate-age population than its dSph counterparts, as well as a non-negligible population of young (<1 Gyr old) stars.
* The distance to Leo I has been estimated to be ~200 kpc, and it has not been detected in HI observations, suggesting it may not be bound to the Milky Way.
* The star formation history (SFH) of Leo I has been studied through the comparison of observed CMDs with synthetic CMDs, and it shows a continuous star formation activity with possible changes in intensity but no big time gaps between successive bursts.
* The presence of bright yellow stars in the CMD of Leo I supports the conclusion that some star formation has likely been going on in the galaxy from 1 Gyr to a few hundred Myr ago.
* The characteristics of the errors in the photometry of Leo I suggest that the faintest stars in the turnoff region are unlikely to be put there due to large errors, indicating the possible presence of stars older than 10 Gyr in the galaxy.

* A hypergeometric system is a system of differential equations with a holonomic rank that coincides with the dimension of its solution space at a nonsingular point.
* The rank of a hypergeometric system can be computed using a combinatorial formula that involves lattice translates determined by the system's matrix and a parameter vector.
* The ranking arrangement of a hypergeometric system is an arrangement of hyperplanes that is used to compute the rank jump of the system.
* The ranking arrangement is contained in the exceptional arrangement, which is the union of an explicit collection of hyperplanes and the ranking arrangement.
* The ranking toric module is a finitely generated graded module that contains the information essential to computing the rank jump of a hypergeometric system.
* The rank jump of a hypergeometric system can be computed from the combinatorics of the ranking lattices of the system at a parameter.
</summary>

- The main laws of quantum mechanics forbid the perfect cloning of quantum states, but approximate copying is possible.
- Quantum cloning machines (QCM) can produce identical or non-identical copies, with copying quality that can be identical for all states or state-dependent.
- QCM have potential applications in quantum cryptography and quantum information science, including eavesdropping on quantum channels.
- This paper discusses "partial" QCM, which copy one constituent of two-partite states, with a focus on mixed states and the purification of mixed states.
- The quality of cloning depends on the quantum state, as shown in figures provided.
- The construction of QCM can be used for cloning mixed states, with the final state produced depending on the reduction of the initial state.
- The paper seeks QCM parameters that minimize the integral average of the distance between the initial and output states.
- The fidelity of the initial and output states for the discussed QCM exceeds the value of 5/6 for most of the Bloch sphere.
- The choice of QCM parameters is defined by the strategy of eavesdropping, and there may be many other variants for QCM.

* Colloidal crystals have the potential to be used in the development of novel materials with unique optical properties, such as iridescent colors and photonic crystals. They can also be used in applications like lasers and display devices. Recent advances have shown the ability to tune the colors through control of lattice spacing with an external field.
* The well-defined thermodynamic temperature of colloidal dispersions allows them to be viewed as mesoscopic "model atoms," and the ability to tune colloid-colloid interactions has led to the observation of a variety of structures. First-order ac electric fields can induce dipolar interactions, leading to anisotropic interparticle potentials and exotic crystal structures. External control of colloid-colloid interactions allows for the observation of phase transitions.
* Direct microscopic observation at the single-particle level allows for an unprecedented level of detail to be accessed, opening up the possibility of tackling long-standing problems in condensed matter, such as freezing. The introduction of a rotating ac field leads to even more possibilities, with disc-like patterns being observed in granular matter and potentially crystalline structures in colloidal dispersions.

• The extinction curve describes how extinction changes with wavelength due to the presence of dust grains in the interstellar medium. Knowledge of the extinction curve is necessary to deredden magnitudes and colors of astronomical objects and to understand the physical properties of dust grains. Cardelli, Clayton, and Mathis (CCM) derived a mean extinction law that depends on one parameter, which they called @xmath0. They considered a sample of 45 reddened Milky Way OB stars and searched for corresponding optical and near-infrared photometry from the literature. They used the intrinsic colors of OB stars for the appropriate spectral types to determine the extinction.

• The CCM law is powerful because it allows one to determine the extinction in some spectral region based on the extinction in a different spectral region, given that one knows @xmath0. The @xmath0 parameter ranges from about 2.0 to about 5.5 when going from diffuse to dense interstellar medium, and it characterizes the dust properties in the region that produces the extinction. Many authors have used this parameter to study extinction, such as searching for a relation between @xmath0 and other parameters that characterize the extinction curves, studying the role of @xmath0 as the main regulatory agent of the penetration of radiation inside dark clouds, and discussing different methods to deredden the data and obtaining a new estimate of the extinction law in terms of @xmath0.

* Quantum computers can perform certain algorithms much faster than classical computers, such as Shor's algorithm for factorizing numbers.
* The basic elements of quantum computation are qubits and quantum logical gates, which can be used to construct any circuit for quantum algorithms.
* Good candidates for the realization of qubits are semiconductor quantum dots with controlled electron numbers, and the qubit state can be encoded using an electron charge or spin.
* Spin qubits have longer decoherence times, which are necessary for quantum computation, but require a magnetic field to prepare and manipulate.
* Another concept for encoding the qubit is based on the singlet-triplet states in a double quantum dot, which can be prepared and manipulated using electrical control of the exchange interactions.
* The qubit states can be controlled using external magnetic fields, spin-orbit or hyperfine interaction, and the qubit state can be read out using current measurement and the effect of Pauli spin blockade.
* Divincenzo et al. suggested building the qubit in a more complex system, namely in three coherently coupled quantum dots, which provides a decoherence-free subspace and purely electrical control of the exchange interactions.
* Recent experimental efforts have been undertaken to achieve coherent spin manipulations in a linear triple quantum dot system according to Divincenzo's proposal, and a new detection method for the qubit state, called the doublet blockade effect, has been proposed.

</summary>

• On October 9, 2006, K. Itagaki discovered a possible supernova (SN) in UGC 4904.
• An upper limit of the @xmath6 magnitude was obtained at @xmath820 days before the discovery.
• An optical transient was observed in 2004, close to the position of SN 2006jc, which was speculated to be a luminous blue variable (LBV)-like event.
• The spatial coincidence between the LBV-like event and SN 2006jc was confirmed, leading to follow-up observations in various wavebands.
• SN 2006jc was classified as type Ib, with many broad features and strong narrow emission lines.
• A bright blue continuum was prominent in the optical spectrum at early epochs, which had also been observed in type II SN 1988z.
• The optical light curve showed a rapid decline, while near-infrared emissions brightened.
• The near-infrared brightening and the fact that the redder side of the He emission profile declined faster than the bluer side were interpreted as evidence of ongoing dust formation.
• The formation of amorphous carbon dust was confirmed by the Akari satellite and the Magnum telescope.
• X-ray and UV emissions were observed by the Swift and Chandra satellites, while radio emission was not detected by the VLA.

- The nature of dark matter remains uncertain, with the possibility of a significant baryonic component.
- The cold dark matter cosmological model, with the addition of dark energy, is successful in describing the growth of structure in the universe, suggesting a major component of dark matter in the form of an elementary particle.
- However, the observed baryons fall short of the total inferred from cosmic microwave background fluctuations, leaving room for a significant baryonic component of dark matter.
- Some authors have proposed models with a large component of baryonic dark matter, including the possibility of cold, self-gravitating molecular clouds.
- A model featuring dense gas clouds predicts gamma-ray emission resulting from cosmic-ray interactions, which could contribute to the diffuse flux in the galactic plane.
- Previous investigations have neglected self-shielding and cascade phenomena, which can be important at high column densities and affect the emergent gamma-ray spectrum.
- The authors present detailed calculations of gamma-ray spectra arising from cosmic-ray interactions with dense gas clouds, using the Geant4 Monte Carlo simulation code.
- The calculations depend primarily on the column density of the individual clouds and their fractional contribution to the galaxy's dark matter halo.
- The authors investigate cosmic-ray interactions with dense gas, where cascade processes and particle transport are important, using the Geant4 Monte Carlo code.
- The calculations assume a spherical cloud of molecular hydrogen of uniform density and temperature, with cosmic-ray protons and electrons injected randomly at a surface point.

- Symbiotic systems (SS) typically consist of a white dwarf (WD), a red giant (RG) star, and circumbinary nebulae.
- The Z Andromedae (Z And) binary system is a SS with a cool giant and a hot compact component, experiencing periods of activity since 1915.
- Outbursts in Z And can be single, double, or in a series with decreasing maximum brightness and different shapes, often accompanied by a jump in the accretion rate and hydrogen burning rate.
- The 1984-1986 outburst in Z And had two maxima, suggesting a double or disturbed single outburst, possibly caused by a drop in WD radiation flux and ejection of material.
- The stellar wind of the cool giant in Z And has a velocity of 25 km/s, which can change the accretion regime and lead to an optical thick wind forming from the WD.
- Collision of the winds from WD and RG leads to shock fronts, increasing the luminosity of the system.
- The observed continuum spectral energy distribution (SED) of Z And can be reproduced by models constrained by the fit of the line ratios, providing a detailed picture of the components.
- The 1984-1986 outburst in Z And can be explained by the collision of the WD wind with two ejected shells from the RG, causing a sudden increase in distance between the WD and the downstream nebula.
- The absence of broad lines and collimated jets during the 1984-1986 outburst suggests no WD explosion or accretion disk presence.
- The 2000-2002 outburst of Z And was characterized by broad wings and collimated bipolar jets, while other SS have shown similar features caused by high-velocity matter accompanying outbursts or accretion disk presence.

- Soft X-ray Transients (SXRTs) in outburst share similar properties with persistent Low Mass X-ray Binaries containing a neutron star (LMXRBs). The large variations in accretion rate in SXRTs allow for the study of regimes inaccessible to LMXRBs. The origin of low luminosity X-ray emission in the quiescent state of several SXRTs is unclear, but it's suggested that a millisecond radio pulsar (MSP) may turn on during this state, creating a link between LMXRBs and recycled MSps.
- AQL X-1, the most active SXRT known, has been extensively studied. Its outbursts are characterized by a fast rise and slow decay. The X-ray spectrum varies with luminosity, transitioning from a soft blackbody to a power law as the luminosity decreases. BEPPOSAX observations allowed for the first detailed study of an SXRT outburst from peak to quiescence.
- The outburst decay of AQL X-1 is reminiscent of the final evolution of dwarf novae outbursts, but there are notable differences due to the different efficiencies in gravitational energy release between white dwarfs and neutron stars. Models of Low Mass X-ray Transient outbursts hosting an old neutron star or a black hole are built in analogy with dwarf novae outbursts, but important differences exist.
- During the February-March 1997 outburst of AQL X-1, Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer (RXTE) observations revealed a nearly coherent modulation at 450 Hz during a type I X-ray burst and a single Quasi-Periodic Oscillation (QPO) peak at two different flux levels. The burst periodicity may represent the neutron star spin frequency or half its value. The possibility of accretion onto the neutron star surface in the quiescent state of AQL X-1 faces serious difficulties, suggesting a transition to the propeller regime.
</summary>

• Single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) networks are emerging as novel electronic materials, and their electrical properties need to be accurately determined for various applications. SWCNT networks can be viewed as a two-dimensional network of conducting one-dimensional rods with large dimension ratio, leading to percolation behavior and nonlinear thickness dependence.

• The frequency- and electric-field dependent conductivity of SWCNT networks have been investigated for individual SWCNTs and some types of SWCNT networks. However, there is a lack of systematic investigation on the correlation between the onset frequency and the length scale determined from nonlinear transport for varying network densities.

• The paper investigates the frequency- and electric-field dependent conductivity for SWCNT networks with systematically varying densities and finds that the onset frequency extracted from the frequency dependence measurement increases with the film thickness, while the length scale extracted from the electric field dependent measurement decreases at the same time. An empirical relation between the two transport measurement methods is developed.

• The investigation of SWCNT networks on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate prepared by the spraying method shows that the networks fit well to the extended pair approximation model, and the onset frequency changes linearly with the dc sheet conductance over about 4 decades. The frequency-dependent conductance of ultra-thin sub-monolayer nanotube networks also fits well to the extended pair approximation model.

• Quantum algorithms, specifically Grover'Search algorithm, can perform certain tasks more efficiently than classical counterparts due to quantum superposition and interference. For example, searching an item in an unsorted database containing N elements can be done in square root of the time required classically.

• Grover'Search algorithm has been realized using various physical systems such as NMR, superconducting qubits, and atom-cavity QED systems. Superconducting qubit-cavity QED is an attractive approach due to its strong coupling limit in microwave cavity. SQUIDs have attracted attention as superconducting qubits due to their design flexibility, large-scale integration, and compatibility with conventional electronics.

• The document discusses the implementation of three-qubit Grover'Search algorithm using four-level SQUIDs in cavity-QED, employing a three-qubit phase gate to reduce the number of quantum gates required. The scheme is based on resonant and off-resonant interaction of cavity field with SQUID transition and application of resonant microwave pulses. The proposed implementation aims to suppress decoherence caused by adjustment of level spacing and reduce the possibility of error.

• The document also discusses various imperfections that can arise during the implementation of Grover'Search algorithm, such as coupling constant, decay rate of level, and cavity decay rate. The fidelity and success probability of three-qubit phase gate and Grover'Search algorithm are analyzed considering these imperfections.

• The phase-field method is a popular tool for simulating microstructure formation during solidification, known for its algorithmic simplicity and avoidance of tracking moving interfaces.
• Some challenges in phase-field modeling include the thin-interface limit, orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification, and the inclusion of microscopic fluctuations.
• The thin-interface limit of two-sided phase-field models cannot eliminate all effects linked to the finite interface thickness.
• The standard equation of motion for orientation fields is not appropriate for the evolution of coherent crystalline matter.
• Microscopic fluctuations cannot be straightforwardly investigated using the standard approach in nucleation processes.
• The precision and performance of phase-field models have been enhanced by controlling their properties, but physical effects due to interface diffuseness must be managed.
• The thin-interface limit is used to analyze the equations of the phase-field model, yielding effective boundary conditions that contain all effects of the finite interface thickness.
• The antitrapping current was introduced to eliminate certain thin-interface effects, allowing for quantitative simulations of alloy solidification, including multi-phase and multi-component alloys.
• The Kapitza resistance, an independent thin-interface effect, cannot be removed by an antitrapping current, posing challenges for developing a general quantitative model.

</summary>

• The 1970s saw the flourishing of many-body theory, with many-body effects on x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra from deep core levels in metals receiving significant attention.
• The excitation of core electrons by XPS can lead to shake-up effects, where conduction-band (CB) electrons are left in a non-equilibrium state, resulting in plasmon replicas in the spectrum.
• The shift in the main peak's position is due to the screening of the core hole by CB electrons, while the plasmon replicas correspond to different excited states of the system.
• In a metal, single-particle excitations can also occur, leading to a deformation of both the main peak and plasmon replicas.
• The low-energy tailing in the XPS line shape is a characteristic of metallic systems and can be used to determine the core hole's location in a complex sample.
• In the case of pristine graphene, the chemical potential is not inside an energy band or a band gap, resulting in a unique system with a low-energy tailing.
• In doped graphene, the chemical potential is inside an energy band, leading to tailing and the contribution of two-dimensional plasmons with a different dispersion than in ordinary three-dimensional metallic systems.
• The collective excitations in doped graphene start from zero frequency and upwards, making it difficult to quantitatively interpret graphene core-hole spectra using Doniach and Sunji fitting.
• The present work aims to provide the reader with the tools needed to calculate the spectra of core-hole in a two-dimensional system.

</summary>

* The text discusses the processes of selection, random genetic drift, and mutations as the underlying mechanisms of Darwinian evolution.
* The dynamics of these processes are typically analyzed in the simplest setting, consisting of two genotypes.
* Fitness is a key concept representing the selection pressure on individuals, defined as the expected number of offspring an individual will produce.
* Experimental studies have shown that many natural systems exhibit frequency-dependent selection, where an individual's fitness depends on its interactions with other individuals and the frequency of different genotypes in the population.
* The impact of nonlinear frequency dependence on coevolutionary dynamics has not been studied theoretically, but the text shows that it may induce new stable configurations of the evolutionary dynamics.
* The article uses the Moran process in a non-spatial environment to study the evolutionary dynamics, which is a well-established model and was already used in many applications.
* The Moran process is a stochastic birth-death process that keeps the population size constant, and in a two-genotype model, the system becomes effectively one-dimensional, so that the dynamics may be described by a one-dimensional Markov chain with transition rates defined by the Moran process.
* The stationary probability distribution of the system dynamics is derived via its Fokker-Planck equation, which reveals metastable points of the dynamics and stochastic switching dynamics between multiple stable points.
* The article is structured in five sections, introducing the model details, deriving the Fokker-Planck equation, analyzing the probability distribution, and summarizing the results.

• The kinetics of polymer loop formation has been studied extensively, with recent focus on its importance in biology. DNA loop formation is crucial for genetic expression, replication, and recombination. Hairpin loop formation is an essential step in protein folding and RNA structure formation.

• Recent experiments have shown the impact of tension on DNA looping. A small tension of 100 femtonewtons can increase the looping time and reduce it in the presence of fluctuating tension. Theoretical studies have explored the effects of nonlinear elasticity, tension, and enzymes on DNA bending and loop formation probability.

• Brownian dynamics simulations of semiflexible polymers treated as extensible wormlike chains, combined with one-dimensional theory of barrier crossing, have been used to understand the basic physical mechanism of biopolymer looping. The simulations show that looping time increases steeply with applied tension and is reduced by dichotomically fluctuating tension.

• The study also highlights the potential of biopolymers to self-organize optimally using ambient nonequilibrium fluctuations, suggesting further experiments with dichotomically fluctuating tension for various chain lengths to establish the resonant activation phenomena in polymer loop formation.

• Weak gravitational lensing by the large-scale structure has been detected in samples of high-redshift quasars (QSOs), intermediate-redshift galaxies, and gamma-ray bursts (GRBs). • The interstellar medium (ISM) of a typical disk galaxy is divided into hot ionized gas, warm neutral medium, and cold neutral medium. The outer, unshielded layers of a PDR are composed of atomic hydrogen and singly ionized carbon, while deeper layers are dominated by the presence of deep penetrating cosmic rays and the freeze-out of molecules onto dust grains. Simply understanding the structure of a non-dynamic, one-dimensional PDR is of limited utility, as the ISM is a dynamic environment where a variety of non-linear, coupled processes determine the global distribution and state of gas.

Explanation:

* The discovery of the VRC in the LMC has been interpreted as an intervening population of stars that may represent a dwarf galaxy or tidal debris. However, this interpretation has been challenged on several grounds, including the lack of evidence for a foreground population in the MACHO team's extensive photometric database and the unlikely hypothesis that the VRC is a clump population.
* The authors argue that the VRC originates in the LMC itself, due to stellar evolution rather than an intervening population. They base this argument on several pieces of evidence. First, they confirm the presence of substructure in LMC red clump morphology corresponding to the VRC. Second, they demonstrate that the VRC corresponds precisely in magnitude and color to the "blue loops" experienced by aging intermediate-mass core helium-burning stars. Finally, they show that similar red clump morphology is present in the cmd of Hipparcos, which probes stellar populations on scales of 5-10 pc from the sun, where intervening dwarf galaxies or tidal debris cannot be invoked. Therefore, they conclude that the VRC originates in the LMC itself due to stellar evolution.

- White dwarf (WD) stars, which represent the end points of stellar evolution for most low-mass stars, are the fate of more than 97% of all stars in our galaxy. A specific type of WD stars, known as da WDs, make up about 80% of all WDs and have hydrogen-dominated atmospheres. When da WDs cool to a certain temperature, they can develop a hydrogen partial ionization zone and start pulsating, going through the zz Ceti (or DAV) instability strip. These pulsations can help determine the fundamental parameters of the WDs using asteroseismology.
* The zz Ceti instability strip is believed to be pure, meaning that all da WDs will eventually pass through it and pulsate as they cool. The strip runs in temperature from roughly 11,000 K for standard WDs with a surface gravity of log g = 8.0. There is also a dependence on surface gravity, with WDs having lower surface gravities pulsating at lower effective temperatures. This trend has been observed for WDs with masses ranging from 1.1 M⊙ down to 0.5 M⊙.
* The discovery of pulsating extremely low-mass (ELM) WDs, which have masses less than 0.25 M⊙ and are likely the product of binary evolution, provides a new opportunity to study the nature of WD pulsations at cooler temperatures and lower masses. These ELM WDs are useful for constraining the interior composition, hydrogen-layer mass, overall mass, rotation rate, and behavior of convection in low-mass WDs. Several groups have investigated the pulsation properties of helium-core WDs, and non-adiabatic calculations have shown that non-radial p- and g-modes should be unstable and observable in these objects.

• The Laor model, which includes the effects of a maximally rotating Kerr black hole, has been widely used to fit the relativistic disc spectral line but sets the dimensionless angular momentum to a canonical value, which cannot be fitted.

• The and laor models have been compared for two sources, mcg-6 - 30 - 15 and gx 339 - 4, which exhibit skewed iron lines, and the model leads to more reliable constraints on the spin value.

* An anomaly in field theory occurs when a symmetry of the classical action or conservation law is violated in the quantized version.

* The creation of two interpenetrating superfluids is a long-sought goal in low-temperature physics.
* Early efforts focused on mixtures of helium isotopes, while recent research has explored condensing two species of atoms simultaneously in the same trap.
* Two different hyperfine spin states of rubidium have been condensed, and the dynamics of their complex relative motion have been studied.
* The possibility of measuring the relative phase between the two condensates has been demonstrated.
* The two condensates have substantial overlap but do not completely interpenetrate each other in the stationary state.
* Theoretical investigation of two-component Bose systems has been ongoing for decades, with recent experiments reviving interest in the theory.

* Two-component systems have more interesting patterns of symmetry and symmetry breaking compared to one-component Bose superfluids.
* The effects of symmetry can be best exposed by explicitly violating the symmetry in a controlled fashion, such as coupling two condensates with an electromagnetic field.
* A sufficiently small violation of the u(1) symmetry corresponding to the relative phase leads to the existence of a nontrivial static configuration, a domain wall, which is a local minimum of the energy but not topologically stable.

• The STE-Quest mission is a medium-sized candidate for the European Space Agency's Cosmic Vision Program, aiming to study the cornerstones of Einstein's Equivalence Principle (EEP) and find possible deviations from General Relativity predictions. The mission comprises a space segment and a ground segment, with precise time- and frequency transfer through bi-directional microwave and optical links. The space segment includes a satellite, two instruments, science link equipment, and precise orbit determination equipment. The ground segment is composed of 3 ground terminals connected to highly accurate ground-clocks.

• The STE-Quest payload primarily consists of an atomic clock and an atom interferometer. The atomic clock is a rebuilt of the high-precision PHARAO clock used in the ACES mission, with an optically derived microwave signal for short-term stability. The atom interferometer uses interference between matter waves to generate a pattern that depends on external forces, performing differential measurements with two isotopes of rubidium atoms to reject unwanted external noise sources. The mission builds on national and European-wide activities, with innovative technologies developed and tested in parabolic flights, drop tower campaigns, and sounding rocket missions.

• The quark-gluon plasma (QGP) is a phase of quantum chromodynamics where quarks and gluons are mostly liberated. Its phase transition structure is a central aim of research in hot and/or dense QCD, with ongoing studies at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider and the Super Proton Synchrotron. The QGP can also be created in the initial stage of a "little big bang" through relativistic nucleus-nucleus collisions in heavy ion accelerators.

• The Landau Fermi liquid theory describes relativistic systems such as nuclear matter, quark matter, and quark gluon plasma. The energy density of weakly interacting quarks in QGP can be evaluated using formulas from this theory, which involve the degeneracy, kinetic and potential energies, and Fermi-Dirac liquid distributions of quasiparticles, as well as the Landau-Fermi interaction function.

• The thermodynamic quantities of the QGP, such as the energy density, entropy, and free energy, can be calculated from the partition function as a function of chemical potential and temperature. These quantities can be rewritten as a function of temperature and baryon density, which is more suitable for experimental measurement. The phase diagram of QGP can be extracted by solving an equation involving the QGP and hadronic pressures.

• The one gluon exchange interaction between quarks is repulsive and helps the interacting quarks and gluons to penetrate from the bag more easily. This interaction makes it easier for the system to transition to the QGP phase. The internal energy density of the QGP is evaluated by performing a summation over the interacting and non-interacting parts of the energy density of quarks, the vacuum energy, and the gluon energy density.

• Dehn surgery is an operation that modifies a three-manifold by drilling and then regluing a solid torus.
• Two Dehn surgeries along a knot with distinct slopes are called purely cosmetic if they result in orientation-preserving homeomorphic three-manifolds.
• The cosmetic surgery conjecture states that two surgeries on inequivalent slopes are never purely cosmetic.
• The paper focuses on purely cosmetic surgeries along knots in the three-sphere.
• For most knots in the three-sphere, the resulting three-manifolds are not orientation-preserving homeomorphic for distinct slopes.
• A knot's Jones polynomial can be used to determine if it admits no purely cosmetic surgery.
• Lescop's surgery formula and a knot invariant satisfying a crossing change formula are used to prove the main result.

• Applications of the main result include proving the nonexistence of purely cosmetic surgery on certain families of two-bridge knots and whitehead doubles.

• Low mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs) are compact binaries where a compact object, such as a neutron star or black hole, is orbited by a low mass star.

• Most persistently bright LMXBs are neutron star systems, which can be divided into two groups: Z sources and atoll sources.

• This problem has gained significant attention in the computer vision community due to its potential applications in various areas such as recognition, image compression, video summarization, and image editing.
• A typical salient object detection model consists of two steps: selecting objects to process and segmenting the object area.
• Current models have bypassed the challenge of selecting objects by focusing on scenes with single objects, and they perform well on the segmentation step for biased datasets.
• However, the performance of these models on complex, cluttered scenes with multiple objects is unclear due to the lack of suitable benchmark datasets and a widely agreed-upon definition of the most salient object.
• The paper aims to address these issues by providing solutions for creating benchmark datasets and identifying the weakest link in the possible failure of models when migrating to complex scenes.
• The paper also discusses related topics to visual saliency modeling and salient object detection, including object importance, object proposal generation, and scene clutter.
• The authors highlight the importance of understanding human attention in designing salient object detection models and the potential of using eye movements to measure object saliency.
• The paper also discusses the limitations of current salient object detection models, including the lack of consideration for high-level semantic knowledge and object information.
• The authors propose the use of a large dataset with explicit saliency judgments and eye movements to improve the performance of salient object detection models.

</summary>

• The axial anomaly is a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, representing a violation of chiral symmetry. It has been analyzed using renormalization procedure and ultraviolet divergences, as well as through the path integral formalism. An alternative approach using dispersion relations and the triangular diagram shows that the anomaly can be interpreted as an infrared phenomenon, caused by a singularity in the chiral limit.

• The Dolgov and Zakharov approach to the axial anomaly has been related to some effects in the dynamics of physical reactions, such as the radiative decays of particles. The authors calculate the corresponding decay rates for the cases where the outgoing leptons are in a definite helicity state and examine the structure of the mass singularities and their cancellation. They also consider the analogies and differences with respect to the corresponding unpolarized decay rates.

• The paper discusses the physics involved in the amplitudes contributing to the absorbitive part of the triangular diagram, including the production and annihilation of a fermion-antifermion pair and the chirality non-conservation in the massless limit. The authors also show that the axial anomaly can be derived by studying the properties of the amplitude in the infrared region.

• The paper also discusses the cancellation of mass singularities in polarized processes and the manifestation of the axial anomaly in reactions where a fermion changes helicity by emitting a photon, which they call helicity changing processes.
</summary>

<summary>

* In their papers, Ozsváth, Szabó, and others constructed a decorated topological quantum field theory (TQFT) in dimension 2, called Heegaard Floer theory.
* This TQFT associates a vector space to a closed, connected, oriented three-manifold and a map to a connected, oriented four-dimensional cobordism decorated with a 2-structure.
* These maps can be used to detect exotic smooth structures on 4-manifolds with boundary.
* For example, two homeomorphic but not diffeomorphic 4-manifolds can be obtained by performing a log transform with odd multiplicity on a regular fiber of the nucleus of an elliptic surface.
* The original definitions of the vector spaces and maps in Heegaard Floer theory involved counting pseudoholomorphic disks and triangles in symmetric products of Riemann surfaces, which are related to the three-manifolds and cobordisms involved via Heegaard diagrams.
* Sarkar and the third author showed that every three-manifold admits a Heegaard diagram that is nice in the sense that the curves split the diagram into elementary domains, all but one of which are bigons or rectangles.
* Using such a diagram, holomorphic disks in the symmetric product can be counted combinatorially, giving a combinatorial description of the Heegaard Floer homology of any three-manifold and null homologous knots and links in any three-manifold.
* A similar result was obtained for all versions of the Heegaard Floer homology of knots and links in the three-sphere.

</summary>
