<summary>

- The invention is a system and method for locating and tracing a concealed, elongated, conductive object, such as a pipe or cable, in the presence of an adjacent object.
* The system includes a transmitter with a pair of antennae that induce distinguishable alternating currents in the objects, and a receiver that senses magnetic fields associated with the currents and produces an output signal dependent upon the sensing of both fields.
* The method involves producing distinguishable alternating currents in the objects, moving a receiver sensitive to the magnetic fields associated with the currents, and producing an output signal from the receiver dependent upon the sensing of both fields.
* The invention improves the ease and accuracy of locating and tracing a desired cable when another cable is present adjacent to it.
* The transmitter of the invention has a pair of antennae that generate corresponding magnetic fields, which induce distinguishable currents in cables. The transmitting apparatus is optimally positioned relative to the cables to produce distinct output signal nulls over the respective cables.
* The system can produce output signal characteristics that are shifted upwardly or downwardly with respect to a base line by adjustment of a receiver deadband control. The receiver is employed to trace a cable in the presence of an adjacent cable, producing output signal characteristics only when the receiver senses both fields associated with the currents in the respective cables.
</summary>

<summary>

• The invention describes an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to enable hands-free automatic answering and communication. It includes a timer for controlling the length of the interconnection and a bypass switch for bypassing the timer.
• The invention aims to provide a device that can be used on private telephone lines or switchboard extensions, making it convenient for the physically handicapped, outpatients, and individuals whose activities make handling a telephone difficult or dangerous.
• The apparatus includes two embodiments of the interfacer. The first one uses an optocoupler to couple the telephone ringing circuit and an optocoupler to connect the speaker phone to the telephone lines automatically. The second embodiment uses a neon lamp optically coupled with a photocell to latch contacts and couple the speaker phone to the telephone line.
• The system includes a two-way speaker phone unit, an interfacing device, and a transformer connected to a local source of power. The interfacing device operates to answer an incoming call automatically and switch the incoming call to the speaker phone unit.
• The system is portable, readily connectable, and can be temporarily installed at a particular location, making it suitable for use during a period of convalescence of an outpatient or at conference or meeting sites.

</summary>

<summary>

* The invention relates to automatically notifying a speaker to decrease their speaking rate when it exceeds a rate that a listener can comprehend, taking into account factors such as the listener's proficiency with the language being spoken, clarity of speech, and network quality.
* The system can include a microphone, a sensory mechanism, a speaking rate processor, a language detector, a speech clarity processor, a comprehension comparator, and a wireless transceiver.
* The sensory mechanism can notify the speaker through various means such as vibration, tone, flashing LED, displayed message, speech message, or haptic indicator.
* The system can determine the language being spoken, the speaker's clarity value for each spoken language, and the listener's listening rate and language proficiency.
* The method includes identifying a discourse involving a speaker and one or more listeners, detecting the language being spoken, determining the listener's identity and listening rate, setting a speaking rate threshold, determining the speaker's speaking rate, and notifying the speaker to reduce their speaking rate if it exceeds the threshold.

</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes a device for the optical recording of rapid processes with a TV camera, which increases the picture sequence frequency to obtain higher resolution in time. It includes means for deviating and suppressing the beam, a cyclic line counter, and a sawtooth generator.
- The cyclic line counter carries out one counting step for each line pulse and supplies an end-of-count pulse after p line pulses, which is applied to the beam suppression circuit of the TV camera for picture beam suppression. The sawtooth generator is synchronized with the output pulses of the counter to control the vertical deviation of the beam.
- The line counter is preferably a programmable counter, and the sawtooth generator and the beam suppression circuit are controlled via a delay device, the delay time of which constitutes a selectable part of a line period.
- The device increases the picture sequence frequency by approximately a factor of 40 compared to a conventional TV half-frame, but the spatial resolution of the picture suffers in the vertical direction. The video signals can be stored in a data processing device for purposes of analysis and can be correlated by a computer.

</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes a system for reducing or eliminating undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and supplying energy to those optical amplifiers over the same branch cables that distribute communication signals.
- The system includes an optical fiber cable trunk configured in a ring topology, with one or more telecommunications hubs serially interconnected, and branching units that allow for convenient add/drop points for telecommunications traffic from the cable trunk.
- Connected to the branching unit is a branch fiber optic cable which is optically coupled at its other end to a cable station, allowing for access to one or more of the signal wavelengths transported along the cable trunk.
- The branch fiber optic cable is used to unidirectionally transmit optical energy at a wavelength other than that of signal wavelength, providing energy for an optical amplifier located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit.
- The hub can also couple optical energy at a wavelength other than signal wavelength onto the optical fiber cable trunk, allowing for energy to be transported along the hub and used for signal amplification.
- This system provides several advantages, including maintaining full connectivity along the trunk and to all cable stations via their respective branch fiber optic cables in the event of a single optical fiber cable trunk cut, and isolating the associated cable station without compromising ring integrity in the event of a branch fiber optic cable cut.
- The system also respects sovereignty concerns, accommodates reconfigurable wavelength add/drop branching units, and allows for repeaterless technology incorporating remote pumping of an optical energy source through the network's branch fiber optical cables, reducing capital, operating, and maintenance costs.

</summary>

<summary>

* The present invention relates to methods and systems for allowing communication between finders of valuable objects and the objects' owners.
* The invention aims to overcome disadvantages of conventional methods, such as providing owner identity information to unknown persons or lacking current contact information.
* The invention includes a unique ID for the owner, registration of the ID with owner contact information, association of the ID with a virtual locale (e.g., a website), and forwarding of finder communications to the owner via the virtual locale.
* The system includes a virtual locale, a database for storing owner contact information associated with a unique ID, and a module for forwarding finder communications to the owner.
* The user interface includes menus for owner and finder operations, such as registering a tag, associating a tag with an object, viewing open cases, and sending messages.
* The system supports various types of tags, such as printed adhesive labels, sew-on patches, plastic key-ring tags, or electronic tags, and can be implemented using various programming languages, operating systems, and database systems.

</summary>

<summary>
• The invention aims to enable multimedia capabilities on existing network devices and customer premises equipment.
• A blended call, which supports voice and multimedia exchanges, is created by sending calls to blender software that initiates parallel voice and multimedia components.
• The invention can be used on various network systems and protocols, and an exemplary embodiment is based on a session initiation protocol (SIP) environment.
• Incoming and outgoing calls associated with a client are routed to the blender associated with the telephony server, which then initiates two parallel components for the call: a voice component and a multimedia component.
• The blender maintains control of the signaling paths of the parallel components so that the bearer path may be controlled to accommodate multimedia requests at any stage during the call.
• The blender software may be implemented in software or sequential logic as is well understood.
• The invention may be integrated with an Intelligent Network (IN) for basic call disposition handling, and the multimedia server may provide mid-call activation of multimedia features.
</summary>

<summary>

• The invention describes a content synchronization framework for connected devices, allowing any device to perform contextual synchronization over various network topologies. It is highly scalable, supports multiple languages and character sets, and enables client devices to have the latest and most relevant content based on user and device context.
• The framework includes a client, at least one central reference point server, a network, and external partners. The client synchronizes content from synchronization servers and/or external partners over the network. The central reference point hosts algorithms, validates client requests, compiles bundle information based on dynamic attribute information, and composes responses with bundle files listed in an order of priority.
• The client device composes a delta list of bundle files that are different from local copies, downloads the files in the ordered delta list, and overwrites local copies with the downloaded bundle files. The framework supports limited bandwidth and connection time by employing data compression for responses and downloaded files.
• The invention also covers the creation of a delta list, handling of synchronization requests and responses, and the flow of content and data between components involved in a synchronization request and response.
</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes a field emission display device with a protection structure to prevent damage to field emission components from ionic emission gas.
- The protection structure includes at least one reduction plate or electrode that deflects ionic emission gas away from the field emission components.
- The reduction plate or electrode is negatively charged to attract positive nitrogen and oxygen ions, which prevents current-induced damage to the field emission elements.
- The reduction plates or electrodes can be elongated and parallel or arranged in a meshwork- or net-shaped pattern among the field emission elements.
- The protection structure can prolong the lifetime of the field emission elements in the device.
- The invention also includes methods for manufacturing the field emission display device with the protection structure.

</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes a method and apparatus for dicing semiconductor wafers using pressure to mechanically separate the individual die from the wafer without a wafer saw. The process involves forming trenches along the scribe lines on a semiconductor wafer and then applying mechanical pressure to the wafer to singulate the individual die.
- The method includes applying a photo resist layer on the wafer surface, patterning it to form openings over the scribe lines, and then etching the wafer through the openings to form trenches along the scribe lines. The trenches can vary in depth, and the wafer can be back-grinded to reduce its overall thickness.
- After the trenches are formed, an adhesive tape is applied to the back-surface of the wafer, which is then placed on a soft pad. Mechanical pressure is applied to the back surface of the wafer, causing a "clean break" along the trenches and singulating the dice on the wafer.
</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes an image sensor with multiple imaging planes, including a top surface and edge surfaces.
* The sensor includes image sensor elements with photodiodes and buried-channel CCDs for charge collection and transfer.
* P+ layers are used to form a waveguide-like structure, guiding charge carriers towards the CCDs.
* The design allows for imaging in a plurality of planes, enabling the sensor to be used in various image formats.
* The sensor can be used to image opposing surfaces or passageways, and can be easily incorporated into existing image sensor processing techniques.
* The thickness of the epitaxial layer determines the effective vertical aperture dimension in the sensor edges.
* The second embodiment of the sensor features extended N-type regions in the CCDs, increasing the lateral extent of the depletion region and improving charge collection.
* The sensor can be used in various applications, such as simultaneous imaging of multiple planes, color applications, and scanning color documents in a single pass.
* The design and construction of the sensor can be modified and varied while still falling within the scope of the invention.

</summary>

<summary>

• The 3-D Phenomenoscope is a system that allows for the viewing of 3-dimensional effects in motion pictures using ordinary film or digital technology.
• It utilizes the Pulfrich effect, where lateral motion in an ordinary motion picture will appear to the viewer in 3-Dimensions when viewed through glasses with individually controlled darkening lenses.
• The glasses have digital photo sensors that capture the viewed motion picture as successive images and convert them to digital images for processing.
• A computer processor and program identify synchronization events in the successive images and control the individual darkening of the right and left hand lenses based on these events.
• The control for the viewing glasses is not a wired, wireless or infrared signal, but information calculated in real-time from successive frames of the motion picture.
• The lenses of the viewing goggles may take 3 different states; clear-clear, clear-darkened, and darkened-clear.
• The viewing glasses look like ordinary lightweight glasses with an attached digital sensor that ‘sees’ and quantifies the digital snapshot captured by the digital sensor.
• The 3-D Phenomenoscope allows for older or motion pictures produced before its invention to be viewed with a 3-dimensional effect.
• It also allows for the viewing of 3-dimensional motion pictures on a TV, DVD player, PC, or in a movie house with battery-powered viewer glasses controlled in real-time by an intelligent processor packaged with the glasses.

</summary>

<summary>
- The source document describes a power management system for home networks that reduces energy consumption by transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device when the master device is not performing its nominal device functions.
* This system ensures that only the best qualified network slave device is promoted to the network master role, thereby maximizing network performance and administration.
* The system includes a master/slave device-network-interface (M/S DNI) for devices capable of serving as both network master and slave nodes, and a slave DNI for devices capable of serving only as network slave nodes.
* The network master node performs network administrative functions such as beacon transmission, device association and authentication, admission control, and bandwidth assignment.
* When the network master node is instructed to enter power save mode, it sends data enabling the network administrative functions to a network slave node, which becomes the new network master node.
* The network master node selects the new network master node based on predetermined selection criteria such as visibility, intelligence/functional capabilities, or user selection.
* A network slave node accepts the transfer of network administrative functions by sending a request reply to the network master node and receiving the transferred functions.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention was made with government support and the government has certain rights in the invention.
• The invention is about electron multipliers used in photomultipliers and particle detectors, specifically channel electron multipliers and microchannel plates.
• Two types of conventional electron multipliers are discussed: discrete dynode multipliers and continuous electron multipliers.
• The foil electron multiplier, a next-generation design, uses a series of thin foils to create secondary electrons and multiply electrons in a series of transmission stages.
• The foil electron multiplier has advantages over other types of electron multipliers, including higher gain per multiplication stage, simplicity of fabrication, lower cost of fabrication, ability to cover a larger area, and intrinsic rejection of ion feedback.
• The apparatus for electron multiplication by transmission includes a foil having a front side for receiving incident particles and a back side for transmitting secondary electrons, contained within a supporting structure in an evacuated enclosure.
• An electrical power supply is connected to the foil and anode to provide an electrical field gradient for accelerating negatively charged incident particles and generated secondary electrons through the foil to the anode for collection.
• The gain of the foil electron multiplier is maximized by maximizing the electron transmission through the foil, maximizing the transmission through the support grid, and maximizing the secondary electron emission yield.
• The gain advantage of the foil electron multiplier lies in the term γSE+1, which is larger than the secondary electron yield for a conventional electron multiplier.
• The foil electron multiplier does not experience ion feedback, as ions generated at the input surface of a particular stage cannot penetrate the foil and initiate another avalanche.
</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes a subminiature lamp assembly with a high temperature polymer that surrounds and is in compression contact with the glass envelope, providing extended axial length sealing, heat resistance, ease of handling, and increased resistance to invasion and chemical attack. The polymeric material is supported by a metal base.
- The seal supported lamp assembly utilizes a polymeric seal support that tightly forms a seal around the glass envelope and extends downward into contact with the upward face of an abbreviated height one piece conductive base. The polymeric seal support also extends downward and over the exterior of the abbreviated height one piece conductive base. The material used for the polymeric seal support should be non-thermally conducting and able to withstand significant subminiature lamp temperature.

</summary>

• The source document describes a patent application for a communications terminal, system, and method for Internet/network telephony. The terminal includes audio means, converting means, protocol means, and wireless communications means for wireless near field communication. The system includes a portable communications terminal, a connecting unit, and a service server. The method includes reproducing sound, converting sound into transmission data, handling communication with the transmission data, and wireless near field communication of the transmission data.

• The terminal is designed to be flexible, not requiring specialized equipment or functionality to provide a connection to a network or the Internet. It can be used for telephony via a network or the Internet and can independently control and communicate data packets according to a standardized Internet/network protocol. The terminal can also dynamically allocate a useful IP address and communicate additional information and/or data with a connecting unit. The wireless data format is preferably a Bluetooth data format.

<summary>

• The document describes a system model for a MU-MIMO system with a base station and user terminals, each with a feedforward filter.
• The base station includes a GDFE Precoder with a feedforward path and a feedback path, which includes an interference pre-cancellation block.
• The GDFE Precoder processes input symbol vectors to produce filtered vector symbols, which are then filtered by a transmit filter to produce a transmitted signal stream.
• The filtered signal stream is transmitted by mapping its elements to the respective antenna elements of the Base Station.
• The received baseband vector corresponding to each user terminal is given by the sum of the product of the feedforward filter and the channel matrix, the product of the feedforward filter and noise, and the product of the interference pre-cancellation step and the filter B.
• The stacked received baseband vector corresponding to all user terminals can be represented as the sum of the product of a block diagonal matrix representing the feedforward filter and the channel matrix, the product of the block diagonal matrix and noise, and the product of the interference pre-cancellation step and the filter B.

</summary>

<summary>

- The document describes an electroluminescent display panel that can display different colors according to situations, without using an intermediate electrode. It is composed of a glass substrate, first and second electrode layers, first and second insulation layers, and first and second luminescent layers. The first luminescent layer emits light with no visible red light components, while the second luminescent layer overlaps the first layer and emits light with visible red light components. By adjusting the voltage level, the panel can display green light (no red) or lemon light (mixture of green and orange).
- The manufacturing processes of the display panel are also explained, involving the formation of ITO layers, luminescent layers, and insulation layers using various sputtering and vapor deposition techniques, followed by heat treatment and electrode formation.

</summary>

Note: The above summary is a brief overview of the main points in the document. It does not include all the details and variations presented in the original text.

<summary>

• The invention describes an antenna array for measuring the elevation angle of a radio wave source, using radio interferometric techniques. The array consists of at least four antennae arranged in equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane, with each triplet having a specific spacing and height of the center element above the ground plane. The system combines and divides the information signals obtained from the antennae to derive a quotient signal that is a function of the elevation angle but not the ground reflection coefficient.

• The antenna array can operate in both receive and transmit modes. In the receive mode, the system provides unambiguous angle measurement through signal processing circuits. In the transmit mode, the transmitted signal from each antenna in the array must be coded to enable angle measurement in a remote receiver. A common coherent carrier is required for the transmissions from each element of a triplet, but coherence between triplets is not necessary.

• The system can be used for various applications, such as determining the range, identity, and elevation angle of an aircraft carrying a suitable transponder. The antenna array can also be used for coding angles in space by energizing specific triplets with coherent carriers and deriving quotients in a remote receiver.
</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes a receiver input circuit that reduces unwanted signal actuation of non-linear components, improving small signal behavior using conventional components. It includes a control loop for amplification control, with a control signal derived from the intermediate frequency signal and supplied to the part of the circuit preceding the mixer stage. Additionally, there is a second and third amplification control loop whose control signal is taken out prior to the mixer stage, with a lower response threshold and frequency bandwidth than the first and second control circuits.
- The input circuit comprises an input network, preamplifier stage, mixer and oscillator stage, intermediate frequency filter, rectifier circuits, and control signal processing circuit. The control signal is obtained from the output of the preamplifier stage and mixer stage, and in the signal frequency selective intermediate frequency amplifier. Amplification is controlled jointly in the input network by means of the control signal processed in the control signal processing circuit.

</summary>

<summary>

* The invention describes a method and device for optimizing the visual impact of an advertising clip inserted into a video sequence. It takes into account the regions of interest of the video sequence and the advertising clip to ensure continuity between them. This is achieved by generating salience maps for the video sequence and each advertising clip, determining the degree of similarity between them, and selecting the advertising clip with the highest degree of similarity for insertion at a predefined insertion point.
* The invention also considers the phenomenon of temporal extension after a shot change in a video sequence, where the spectator continues to fixate on the area they were previously fixated on for approximately 200 to 300 ms. By ensuring continuity between the regions of interest of the video sequence and the advertising clip, the invention helps to immediately perceived the content of the advertising, increasing its visual impact on the spectator.

</summary>

<summary>

• The invention relates to a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, specifically an axial fan with an increased intake airflow rate and a housing that enhances heat-dissipating performance.
• Conventional fans have restrictions in dimension and construction, limiting air intake and fan housing design.
• The invention's fan and housing address these limitations by extending the sidewall of the housing to increase the intake airflow area without modifying assembling conditions.
• This extension allows for a larger impeller, increasing airflow rate and heat-dissipating efficiency.
• The air passage formed by the sidewall of the housing reduces gradually and evenly in cross-sectional area, concentrating air streams to the center and blowing to the heat sink's highest temperature portion.
• The housing design (first aspect) includes an outer frame with a passage for air streams, having a sidewall extending radially outwards for intake/discharge area enlargement.
• The sidewall extends in a symmetrical, frustum-conical, or frustum-elliptically conical manner and may include an inclined portion or beveled edge.
• The housing design (second aspect) focuses on the air inlet side, extending the sidewall radially outwards to enlarge the intake area, with optional inclined portion, notch, or frustum-conical shape.
• The heat-dissipating device (third and fourth aspects) includes an impeller and housing with an enlarged intake/discharge area, and the impeller's blade dimension increases with the sidewall's radial extension.
• The heat-dissipating system (fifth and sixth aspects) includes a casing, electrical elements, and a heat-dissipating device with an impeller and housing, having a radial extension for intake/discharge area enlargement.

</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to using a recessed mask structure to prevent high electrical fields and reduce electrical breakdown in small dimension semiconductor devices.
• The problem of high electrical fields is due to dimensional tolerances becoming very small and abrupt physical discontinuities in miniaturized semiconductor devices.
• The invention provides a metal plus low dielectric constant (low-k) interconnect structure for a semiconductor device, which reduces lateral leakage current and lowers the effective dielectric constant.
• The mask member is positioned below the surface to be planarized, at a location where the surfaces of the regions separated by the dielectric are undisturbed and have complete integrity.
• The invention is particularly useful in the damascene type device structure, wherein adjacent conductors are disposed in thin trenches in an intralevel dielectric material (ILD), connections are made to levels above and below through metal filled vias, and masking is employed for protection and patterning.
• The recessed mask structure provides a lower and predictable overall capacitance, resulting in faster signal propagation in the interconnect wiring.
</summary>

<summary>

• The invention relates to a system and method for spontaneously setting up a collaborative work-share environment between physically distant individuals.
• The system uses network-enabled applications to enable sharing of information, video conferencing, and other collaboration features while maintaining an initial voice connection.
• The system uses a collaboration button and indicator on a telephone set, which are activated when the system determines that the parties involved have the capability to collaborate.
• The collaboration control program on each PC communicates with the phone to control the collaborate indicator and sense actuation of the collaborate button.
• The call control unit includes a plurality of Phone Proxies, each associated with a telephone and maintaining the call state for that telephone.
• The collaborate indicator is initialized by a Call Completed event, and the collaborate control program compares the list of supported application programs with those supported by the remote PC to determine whether the mutual collaboration application programs can inter-operate in a shared work environment.
• The collaborate indicator remains illuminated provided that at least one other party remains in the call with the capability to collaborate with the initiating telephone.
• The system can be implemented in various architectures, including a peer-to-peer architecture, and can be integrated within a computer with the indicator and collaborative button provided by an input device of the computer.

</summary>

<summary>

* The document describes a Downconverting Digitizer that converts and downconverts a modulated IF signal to baseband in-phase and quadrature components, and controls the processed modulated IF signal amplitude to extend the dynamic range of the digitization process and minimize quantization noise.
* The Digitizer comprises a digitally-controlled variable gain amplifier, a gain control logic element, an analog summing element, a sampling element, a predictive digital filter, an offset nuller element, a digital summing element, a digital to analog converter, a digital quadrature mixer, and two rate reduction filters.
* The Digitizer operates on the principle of generating a digital prediction of the input signal through the feedback path signal, and uses a predictive loop to minimize the prediction error signal.
* The sampler element converts the loop error signal from an analog to a digital representation, and can be implemented as a 1-bit analog-to-digital converter consisting of a limiter amplifier and a D flip-flop.
</summary>

<summary>

* The invention describes a method and system for a mobile terminal to switch between a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN) for voice/data communication.
* The WLAN contains a second base station that gathers service information about neighboring base stations in the WWAN, including signal strength, channel information, and base station identity codes. This information is broadcasted by the first base stations in the WWAN.
* When the mobile terminal connects to the WLAN, the second base station transmits the service information to the mobile terminal. This information allows the mobile terminal to skip some of the connection setup time when connecting to the WWAN.
* The mobile terminal contains a first network module (e.g. GSM module) for connecting to the WWAN and a second network module (e.g. WiFi module) for connecting to the WLAN and receiving the service information.

</summary>

Note: The above summary is a generalized explanation of the source document and may not include all the details. For a complete understanding, it is recommended to refer to the source document.

<summary>

- The present invention describes a method and system for singulating and plating semiconductor packages, which includes plating the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe to prevent contamination of the lead surfaces.
- The method includes providing a plurality of semiconductor dies coupled to a single common leadframe, encasing the semiconductor dies and leadframe in a molding compound, singulating the plurality of semiconductor dies by cutting the leadframe between adjacent semiconductor dies, and plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads with a plating material.
- The system includes a leadframe having a top surface and a bottom surface, a semiconductor die attached to the bottom surface of the leadframe, and a molding compound at least partially encasing the leadframe and semiconductor die, where the side surfaces of the leads are exposed through the molding compound and plated with a plating material.
- The plating material can be a metallic material such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold.
- The singulation process can be performed using full cutting or partial cutting techniques, and the plating process can be performed before or after the singulation process.
- The invention provides several advantages, including improved reliability, reduced cost, and increased manufacturing efficiency.

</summary>

<summary>

* The invention relates to a method for fabricating arrays of nano-scale features on a single wafer to form a sensor device or a matrix of devices for multiplex detection of selected analytes.
* The method uses nanoimprint lithography to define groups of semiconducting nanotraces between electrodes, which can be used as a sensor or for multiplex detection of analytes.
* Nanoimprint lithography also provides a method to fabricate arrays of semiconducting electrode "nanotraces" in a controllable and regular pattern in a single processing step.
* Binding of complementary targets to anchored probe molecules in the vicinity of the semiconducting active layer produces a change in electrical conductivity of the semiconducting active layer that can be monitored externally for each sensor device in the array in parallel.
* The method can be used to detect gases adsorbed on the semiconductor surfaces or multiplex detection of many simultaneous detection zones.
* The fabrication process includes the creation of a template for nanoimprint lithography, the deposition of a semiconducting active layer, and the transfer of the imprint pattern to form the semiconductor nanotraces.
* The nanotraces have a high surface-to-volume ratio, which makes them highly sensitive to changes in their local environment.
* The method is cost-effective, time-efficient, and reproducible, and can be used to detect changes in electrical characteristics of the nano-scale materials for each device.

</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination, specifically for precisely measured laboratory foam sheet cross-sectional specimens. The apparatus includes a base structure for stabilization, a clamping arrangement to grasp the foam sheet specimen, a screw thread specimen advance mechanism, and a planar surface for the interaction with a cutting knife to ensure uniform thickness and parallel cut edges.
- The invention also provides a method for preparing foam test samples that have at least two cut sides that are parallel to one another, preserving the structure of the individual cells within the sample for examination without undue distortion or mutilation. The precise parallel orientation of the cut surfaces of the foam samples allows for even transmission of light through the specimen during microscopic examination.

</summary>

- High-dielectric oxide materials, such as ferroelectric materials, are useful in semiconductor circuitry for capacitors, MOS transistors, pixels for light detecting arrays, and electrooptic applications.
* Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric materials are convenient due to their low annealing temperatures and desirable properties in small grains.
* However, Pb and Bi are very reactive and can diffuse into and through metals, causing issues when growing oxides on Si.
* A Ge buffer layer on Si can prevent or minimize the formation of the low dielectric constant layer caused by the oxidation of Si.
* An epitaxial Ge layer on Si provides a good buffer layer for many oxides and is compatible with Si process technology.
* Epitaxial growth of Ge on top of the ferroelectric or high-dielectric constant oxide is easier than Si, allowing for the formation of three dimensional epitaxial structures.
* A Ge buffer layer on the Si or GaAs substrate allows for the epitaxial growth of many more oxides due to the smaller chemical reactivity of Ge with oxygen.
* However, not all oxides are stable next to Ge. For example, Pb-containing ferroelectrics are not thermodynamically stable next to Ge. A thin layer of SrTiO3 or other stable ferroelectric can be used as a buffer layer between the Pb-containing ferroelectric and the Ge coated Si substrate.
* An epitaxial Ge and non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric material buffer layers can solve the problem of integrating Pb/Bi-containing ferroelectrics on GaAs.
* A method for fabricating a structure useful in semiconductor circuitry includes growing a buffer layer of non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide layer directly or indirectly on a semiconductor substrate and depositing a Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide on the buffer layer.

</summary>

• The document is a patent application for cellular lattice structures with multiple cell sizes and related methods of use.
• The invention was made with support from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency/Office of Naval Research.
• The invention relates to cellular materials used in structural applications, specifically to materials with hierarchical cellular lattices.
• Sandwich panels are a primary application for the invention, used in various fields such as transportation, ballistics, thermal transfer, and construction.
• The lattice structure is formed by a network of hierarchical trusses, synergistically arranged to provide support and other functionalities.
• The structure is generally hollow, maintaining low weight while providing high specific stiffness and strength.
• The invention includes structures with nested and mated lattice structures, as well as methods for making these structures.
• The patent application includes figures illustrating the lattice structures, arrays, and methods of making them.
• The invention has various potential applications, including in transportation, ballistics, thermal transfer, multifunctional structures, armors, load bearing materials, construction materials, and containers.
• The patent application includes a wide range of claims, covering various aspects and embodiments of the invention.

</summary>

<summary>
• The invention describes a method for preparing a superconducting device using an oxide superconducting material, where a blocking film is used to prevent the removal of oxygen from the surface.
• The method involves forming a film using an photo CVD method, followed by adding oxygen using methods such as ion injection or hot oxidation, and heat treating the material to position the added oxygen in the appropriate atom location.
• The film can be an insulating film such as silicon nitride, aluminum nitride, or oxidized aluminum, or a metal or semiconductor that becomes an oxidized insulating film after oxidizing treatment.
• The method can be used with a superconducting material in tablet or thin film form, and can be used to create a Josephson element structure or a passivation film.
• The invention aims to provide a highly reliable superconducting device with consistent conductivity characteristics at the surface and internal portions.
</summary>

<summary>

- The invention describes a process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons using an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) process and a hydrocarbon production process. Coal is gasified in a wet gasification stage to produce a combustion gas at elevated pressure, which is then used to generate power and enrich a first portion of the combustion gas with hydrogen. The enriched gas is then mixed with a synthesis gas precursor produced in a dry gasification stage to synthesize hydrocarbons.
- The process aims to show economic and environmental benefits by integrating the IGCC process with a hydrocarbon production process. The wet gasification stage uses water as a carrier for solid feedstock, while the dry gasification stage uses a gas as a carrier. The molar ratio of H2/CO in the combustion gas is higher than that in the synthesis gas precursor, and the dry gasification stage produces synthesis gas at a sufficiently high pressure for hydrocarbon synthesis.

</summary>

<summary>

• The invention describes a process and apparatus for producing multilayered electrical components, such as capacitors and coils, with improved efficiency and reduced labor costs.
• The process involves providing a first electrode and a first electrical component in a recess to form a first laminate sub-assembly, and repeating the process with a second electrode and a second electrical component to form a second laminate sub-assembly. These sub-assemblies are then stacked together to form a resultant assembly.
• The electrodes and electrical components can be formed on decals using a screening process, and can be interconnected using various methods. The sub-assemblies can be located in precise registered relation, and can be built up with covering components at upper and lower ends of the stacks.
• The resulting assemblies can be fabricated at low cost and at high production rates, and can be used for various electronic applications such as capacitors, coils, resistances, or combinations thereof.
• The invention also includes apparatus or tooling to enable such fabrication, as well as the resultant sub-assemblies and assemblies themselves.
• The method can also be adapted to other electronic ceramic devices such as multilayer ferrite inductors, multilayer substrates, semiconductor packages, and precision registers.

</summary>

<summary>

• The invention is a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of seismometers, especially those used on the ocean floor.
• The apparatus includes a pendulum with a geophone suspended at the end of a shaft, which allows the geophone to align with the vertical axis when the seismometer is in its normal, up-right position.
• A plunger with a head made of synthetic rubber is used to lock the geophone in place, and a coil spring ensures sufficient force is applied to prevent further motion or rotation.
• A pin is held in place by a solenoid to prevent the plunger from coming into contact with the geophone, and is removed when it is time to lock the geophone in place.
• The angle of inclination can be determined by measuring the acute angle between the longitudinal side wall of the shaft and a surface known to be vertical when the seismometer is in its normal, up-right position.
• The invention also includes a method for self-leveling seismic motion detectors when employed as the pendulum weight.
• The invention aims to provide a simple and inexpensive method for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer, preserving its orientation, and providing good acoustic coupling between the ocean bottom and the detector.
• The invention can be used in seismometers with vertical or horizontal-type seismic motion detectors.
• The invention can be used until the seismometer is pitched over at almost 90° from its normal, up-right position.

</summary>

<summary>

• The invention describes an improved IP telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as a more convenient, economical, and efficient IP telephone.
• The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder for low power consumption and can be used with a relatively low-performance PC for effective IP telephony.
• The enhanced radio telephone can transmit and receive digitized and coded speech signals via an alternate external connection, allowing it to operate as either a conventional radio telephone or as an improved IP telephone.
• Coded and compressed digital speech signals are passed back and forth between the enhanced radio telephone and the PC, and the PC performs conversions between the coded speech signals and an appropriate computer network protocol.
• In alternative embodiments, the enhanced radio telephone is also used for wireless data communication in order to carry IP speech, with coded speech passed from the enhanced radio telephone to the PC where it is formatted according to an appropriate UDP/IP network protocol.
• The invention provides an improved IP telephone which is more convenient, economical and efficient as compared to conventional IP telephony systems.

</summary>

- The invention describes a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a cigarette production and/or packaging machine.
* The detection process uses an optical checking element, such as a camera, to scan and evaluate images of cigarettes in the magazine, producing an error signal if a scanned image deviates from a reference image or value.
* The detection apparatus includes an optical checking element, an image-processing device, and means to produce an error signal. It monitors a larger area of cigarettes, rather than individual ends, to detect transversely located cigarettes and register defects such as missing filters, bent or broken cigarettes.
* A disruption can be eliminated manually or automatically, with an error signal indicating the need for intervention.
* The elimination process involves detecting a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette and actuating an ejecting unit to remove a plurality of cigarettes from an assigned ejecting zone.
* The elimination apparatus includes one or more ejecting units arranged in the region of the magazine, which can eject a sufficient number of cigarettes to remove transversely located cigarettes.

<summary>

* This patent application relates to a motor assembly with a force transmission structure for a vehicle window lift system.
* The force transmission structure includes a drive plate with a Y-shaped mounting hole and a shaft with a Y-shaped toothed portion that fits into the mounting hole.
* The shaft is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip located within a groove in the distal end of the toothed portion.
* The drive plate is made of a plastics material, and the damper is made of rubber.
* The shaft further comprises a pinion for driving a gear of a window lift system.
* The gear train includes a worm driven by the motor, a worm gear meshed with the worm, and a damper attached to and rotatable with the worm gear.
* The drive plate is driven by the worm gear through the damper.
* The worm comprises an inner ring, an outer ring, and a plurality of ribs extending from the inner ring to the outer ring.
* The damper is received in a space formed between the inner ring and the outer ring and has a plurality of first slots for fittingly receiving the ribs respectively.

</summary>

<summary>

- The invention relates to a scraped surface heat exchanger with an improved method and apparatus for mounting blades onto the drive shaft using a pin type connection.
* The blade has L-shaped locking tracks on both sides, which interfere with the pin and lock the blade against longitudinal movement while permitting pivoting movement relative to the drive shaft.
* The pin includes an inner finger and an outer finger, with the base of the pin mounted to the drive shaft.
* The blade is placed at an angle relative to the pins, and the fingers of the pin slide into the entry tracks of the locking tracks.
* The blade is then inserted between the fingers of the pin, and the inner finger aligns with the mounting holes of the blade.
* The intermediate slot of the locking track extends only as far as the hole, while the intermediate track extends past the hole to accommodate the width of the outer finger.
* The blade can be angularly rotated downward into an installation position, where it is at a sufficiently shallow angle to fit within the outer tube of the heat exchanger.
* The blades will not fall downward off the pins no matter what angle they are at, ensuring the correct orientation and preventing any out-of-track movements.

</summary>

<summary>

• The invention describes a multiorifice wafer structure with angularly disposed passages and a method for making it. The structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods interspaced with cylindrically shaped members at progressively larger angles. The fused assembly is then cut into thin wafers, creating interstices that form a plurality of angularly disposed passageways with increasing angles as the distance from the center increases.
• The multiorifice structure is designed to have a plurality of passageways angularly disposed with respect to a common axis, with the angular displacement increasing as a function of the displacement from the center. This design aims to create a flat multiorifice spray plate for a fuel injector valve, where the fuel passing through the spray plate is ejected at an angle that depends on the orifices' distance from the center.
• The invention also presents a simple and economical method for fabricating the multiorifice structure. It involves twisting rods or wires around a core rod and sheathing them in cylindrical members. The process is repeated, creating multiple layers of rods and cylindrical members, which are then fused or sintered into an integral structure. The integral structure is sliced or cut to produce thin multiorifice structures with the desired thickness.

</summary>

<summary>

• The document describes a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver in a wireless communication system. The system includes an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem with a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator, and a baseband subsystem with a free running counter. The free running counter provides a mobile time reference and has a wake mode and a sleep mode. In the wake mode, it uses the high frequency oscillator to generate the mobile time reference, and in the sleep mode, it uses the low frequency oscillator to maintain the mobile time reference.
• The mobile time reference is used for detection, identification, and monitoring of multipath signals in WCDMA systems. Multipath signals are identical signals from the same antenna reaching the receiver at different times due to taking different paths. The system maintains the mobile time reference during idle mode to allow the portable transmitter to quickly transition to an active state, reducing power consumption and extending battery life.
• The system includes a WCDMA modem with a free running counter (FRC), a receiver equalizer, a multipath monitor, and a multipath radio signal recovery circuit. The FRC provides a timing reference for the portable transceiver system and for acquiring the parameters required to recover the multipath signals and operate a multipath signal receiver. The digital signal from the receiver BAP is provided to the receiver equalizer and equalized prior to being provided to the multipath monitor and multipath radio signal recovery circuit.

</summary>

<summary>

• The text describes a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device with an LDD (Lightly Doped Drain) structure, which aims to improve the controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall, enable the formation of an LDD structure by a low-temperature process, and prevent degradation of the transconductance and increase of resistances due to hot-carrier injection into the oxide portion on the gate sidewall.
• The method involves forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, substrate, and sidewall therebetween, followed by forming a conformal layer on the insulating film and anisotropically etching away the layer using RIE, leaving a portion on the gate sidewall. An insulating layer is then formed on the gate electrode, and a low density region of the source/drain region is formed by ion injection of an impurity using an oxide film of the gate and an insulating film on the gate as a mask. After forming a conductive layer on a wafer, it is anisotropically etched away to leave a portion on the sidewall of the gate. The mask is then removed, and the high density region of the source/drain region is formed by ion injection of an impurity.

</summary>

Note: The summary is a generalization of the main ideas presented in the text, and it does not cover all the details and specific embodiments described in the text.

<summary>

- The invention describes a helmet liner with a plurality of layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets, each with an array of pockets, arranged in superposed contacting relationship with one another.
- The liner is fitted to an individual's head by heating the sheets to a plastic state, placing the liner between an outer fixture and the wearer's head to deform the sheets to the proper extent, and removing the liner when it has cooled to a rigid, nonplastic state.
- The pockets of each layer are open and unfilled, allowing for deformation in response to compressive contact with an adjacent layer, simplifying the manufacturing process and improving the liner's ability to conform to the contours of the wearer's head.
- The helmet comprises an outer shell with a rigid outer layer formed of reinforced plastic material and an energy-absorbing polystyrene foam liner carried inside the outer layer.
- The inner liner is made up of four sheet layers formed of a suitable elastic thermoplastic material, each vacuum-formed over a hemispherical dome with regularly spaced hollow spherical protuberances.
- The layers are trimmed to the required shape, glued together, and attached to a hemispherically patterned layer of comfort foam and a sewn knit fabric inner lining or cover.
- The liner is custom-fitted to the head of the wearer by heating it in an oven, placing it inside the shell or a fitting fixture, and pressing it firmly downward until it has cooled and solidified, allowing for subsequent adjustment to accommodate a changed head size.

</summary>

<summary>

* The invention is about devices for producing power or useful work from surface waves on a water body, using submerged devices that rely on differences in hydrostatic pressure and enhanced surge or pitch.
* Wave energy commercialization lags behind wind energy due to high cost per unit of energy capture, caused by heavy steel construction for severe sea-state survivability and low wave energy capture efficiency.
* Only about 10% of currently proposed ocean wave energy converters (OWECs) are deployed subsurface, where severe sea-state problems are reduced.
* Most subsurface OWECs are designed for near-shore sea bed deployment, but ocean waves lose substantial energy as they approach shore due to breaking, reflected wave, bottom and hydrodynamic friction effects.
* Near-shore submerged sea bed OWECs must be deployed at greater depths relative to average wave trough depths due to severe sea-state considerations, and depth can not be adjusted for the large tidal depth variations found at higher latitudes.
* Wave induced subsurface static pressure oscillations diminish more rapidly in shallow water as the depth below waves or swell troughs increases.
* Only a few prior art subsurface devices use gas filled or evacuated containers like the present invention, producing container deformation in response to overhead swell and trough induced static pressure changes.
* None of the prior art subsurface OWECs capture both hydrostatic (heave) and hydrokinetic wave energy (surge or pitch) which represents half of all wave energy.
* None of these prior art subsurface OWECs enhance or supplement energy capture with overhead floating bodies.
* All of the prior subsurface deformable container OWECs suffer from high mass (and therefore cost) and low energy capture efficiency (even more cost) usually due to near-shore or sea bed deployment and high mass.

</summary>

<summary>
- The invention describes a fixing mechanism for a tool used in machining materials, such as wood, plastics, or metal. The mechanism includes a tool, a frame, and a tool holder in the frame of a machine tool.
- The fixing mechanism can be used in various applications, including machining by chipping, cutting, punching, molding, and forming work, particularly in machining of metal sheets in sheet machining centers.
- The mechanism uses a curved surface for connecting the tool frame and the tool holder, which overcome the disadvantages of the commonly used conic fit.
- The mechanism is simple, secure, and can transmit machining force between the tool frame and the tool holder.

• The humidity sensing element of the present invention is a small, hollow cylinder made of commercially pure (99.4%) aluminum with an outer flange for mounting and a fine, smooth-finished bore that serves as the moisture sensing portion. The bore is anodized to form a porous layer of aluminum oxide, which is then impregnated with nickel particles using vacuum deposition. The anodized layer is sealed, and a thin, water vapor pervious electrode is formed over the nickel-impregnated sealed anodized layer using vacuum deposition of nickel atoms. This results in a doped dielectric layer formed by the nickel impregnated sealed portion of the anodized layer, which is vapor pervious and electrically conductive.

• The sensor is mounted in a mounting bracket with a bore and counterbore for receiving the cylindrical portion and flange of the sensor, and a clamping ring of non-conductive material equipped with screws for firmly mounting the sensor. A thin plastic insulating ring is adhesively fastened to the flanged outer end of the sensor, and a layer of electrically conductive material is applied to cover the second electrode for a short distance within the bore and to extend unbroken over the inside diameter of the plastic ring and over its exposed flat surface. A metal ring is then clamped over the conductive layer to make a suitable pressure electrical contact with the second electrode without inadvertently crushing the doped dielectric layer that could effectively short circuit the two electrodes.

• The sensor functions based on the theory that while the capacitance of a porous dielectric between electrodes will increase linearly with the number of water vapor molecules present in the dielectric, the resistance of many materials increases as the temperature increases. In the present sensing element, water vapor molecules in the presence of the ion-forming aluminum monohydrate in contact with the nickel particles in the anodized layer will form conductive ionization paths between the nickel particles and lower the resistance in the path between the electrodes. • The text describes a continuation of a patent application for switching circuitry used to drive display drivers, aiming to operate at high speeds with low electromagnetic interference (EMI).
• Two common techniques for generating supply voltages to display driver circuits are charge pump circuits and switching regulator circuits. Charge pumps have high energy efficiency but limited current capability, while switching regulators offer high current but lower energy efficiency and generate EMI.
• The invention provides methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits with high efficiency and low EMI using modified switching regulator circuits.
• The modification involves creating multiple circuit paths carrying current in opposite directions to cancel out radiated noise and adding terminal lines to sink any EMI generated in the outermost paths.
• This invention enables the production of large currents for driver circuits of large displays, such as the Apple iPhone display, without the typical penalties associated with EMI or noise.
• The reduction in EMI can be further increased through the use of terminal leads.
• Media player apparatus operating in accordance with the methods and circuits of the present invention are also provided.
</summary>

<summary>

* The invention describes a device for interconnecting high voltage cables with an apparatus or a second cable, consisting of a cable termination and a rigid insulator. The aim is to simplify the connection system for high voltage cables up to 400 KV and above, by providing a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections.
* The device uses three interface methods: an inner cone concept, an outer cone concept, and a no cone or slight inner cone concept. The outer cone concept separates the cable connection further from the apparatus it is connected to, making it less likely for a fault at one side to affect the other side. The inner cone concept allows for a shorter solution outside an SF6 cubicle, but may face problems with coned surfaces made by different suppliers. The substantially plane surface interconnection simplifies complete alignment of the meeting surfaces without risking glow discharges.
* The invention includes various applications such as SF6 terminals, transformer terminals, out-door terminals, straight through joints, transition joints, and joints between two apparatus. The rigid insulator used in these applications should have a conical interface surface with an angle between 15° and 45° to optimize the product's operating reliability in high or extra high voltage installations.
</summary>

• The source document describes a method for rebalancing and charging a battery in a vehicle, where the cells in the battery are caused to acquire charge at different rates for a certain period of time such that their voltages become approximately equal at the end of that period. This process may take up to 50% of the total time required to rebalance and charge the battery.

• The document also provides equations for calculating the maximum capacity and energy content of a battery cell, as well as a method for determining the desired voltage needed to provide a specified energy content in the battery pack.

• The method for charging the battery pack involves determining the required state of charge (SOC) for each cell based on the target post-charge cell voltage, and then calculating the required ΔSOC that can be substituted into equation (1) to determine the ΔIhr required to charge an individual cell. The time required to charge the battery pack is dependent on the cell requiring the greatest ΔIhrs, the cell requiring the least ΔIhrs, the method of balancing the cells to the same voltage, and the portion of the charge cycle selected to balance the cells.
</summary>

• GAO has been assessing strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade.
• Strategic sourcing can encompass various tactics to acquire products and services more effectively and efficiently.
• Private sector companies use spend analysis as a foundation for strategic procurement, while the federal government is not fully leveraging its buying power.
• OMB implemented strategic sourcing practices in 2005, and the Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative (FSSI) was established to address government-wide opportunities.
• In 2011, the DOD, DHS, DOE, and VA accounted for 80% of federal procurement spending, but only managed about 5% through strategic sourcing efforts.
• FSSI had only managed a small amount of spending through its initiatives in 2011, but reported achieving significant savings.
• Agencies that used strategically sourced contracts generally reported savings, but realizing cost savings depends on utilization of these contracts.
• Data, expertise, leadership support, and metrics are significant challenges for agencies in implementing strategic sourcing.
• Companies tailor their tactics based on the complexity of the service and the number of suppliers for that service.
• Leading company practices include maintaining spend visibility, developing category strategies, focusing on total cost of ownership, and regularly reviewing strategies and tactics.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) of 1995, Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sections 4911 and 162(e) have different definitions of lobbying activities and covered officials. LDA covers only federal officials, while IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) cover state and local officials as well. LDA does not cover grassroots lobbying, while IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) do. The definitions of covered officials also differ, with LDA covering more executive branch officials for nonlegislative matters and IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) covering more levels of executive branch officials for legislative matters.

• The differences in definitions can significantly affect who must register and what they must report under LDA. In 1997, 1,824 organizations lobbied on their own behalf and filed reports under LDA, with most reporting using the LDA definition. However, organizations using the IRC section 162(e) definition had the highest mean and median expenses reported. The choice of definition can also affect whether an organization must register under LDA and what information it must disclose on its semiannual lobbying report.

• LDA requires the Comptroller General to report to Congress on the differences among the definitions of certain lobbying-related terms found in LDA and the IRC, the impact of any differences among these definitions on filing and reporting under the act, and any changes to LDA or to the appropriate sections of the IRC that may be recommended to harmonize the definitions.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007, due to material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in internal control. This resulted in a material weakness in SEC's financial reporting process, including issues in period-end financial reporting, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures. Three significant deficiencies were also identified in internal control, concerning property and equipment, and accounting for budgetary resources.

• The SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were fairly stated in all material respects, but the weaknesses in internal control may adversely affect decisions based on inaccurate information and result in misstatements in unaudited financial information. Control deficiencies were found in SEC's period-end financial reporting process, calculation of accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures, constituting a material weakness.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is responsible for aviation safety oversight, air traffic control (ATC), and airport infrastructure development.
• The costs associated with FAA's activities are primarily driven by the volume and nature of the services provided, with safety activities based on the number of licenses and inspections, and ATC costs influenced by the amount and nature of services used by each flight.
• The Airport Improvement Program (AIP) is funded through a multibillion-dollar grant program, but unlike safety and ATC services, AIP expenditures are not directly linked to costs imposed by users of the National Airspace System (NAS).
• The Trust Fund, established in 1970, is credited with revenues collected from system users through dedicated excise taxes, including ticket taxes, passenger segment taxes, fuel taxes, and international arrival/departure taxes.
• The National Civil Aviation Review Commission identified concerns with FAA's funding structure, recommending that FAA's revenues be more closely linked to the costs of services provided to support ATC activities, including capital investments.
• Some stakeholders support the current excise tax system, while others, including FAA, raise concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency under the current system.
• Alternative funding options for collecting revenues from NAS users present advantages and disadvantages, with the degree of linkage between revenues and costs depending on the contributions required from users.
• The two options reviewed for modifying the current excise tax structure are relying solely on a fuel tax and increasing the passenger segment tax to replace the passenger ticket tax.

</summary>

<summary>

• The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal grant program that aims to improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records used by various national systems, including the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) for firearm background checks.

• States have used NCHIP grant funds to automate criminal history records and make them accessible nationally, with the percentage of automated records increasing from 79% in 1993 to 89% in 2001. However, there are still limitations in the availability and accessibility of records related to firearm disqualifiers, such as domestic violence misdemeanor convictions and mental health commitments.

• NCHIP funds have been used to improve access to domestic violence records and set flags on the records of persons with domestic violence convictions, but problems in identifying domestic violence misdemeanor convictions persist due to the lack of automated misdemeanor data and the difficulty in distinguishing domestic violence offenses from other assault charges.

• Mental health records are often not available nationally due to state mental health laws, privacy laws, or doctor-patient considerations, and federal law is unclear regarding who is a prohibited person in reference to substance abuse, making it difficult for states to make records available for NICS checks.

• NCHIP is an "umbrella" program that pools or coordinates various streams of monies and generally provides seed money or supplemental funds for states to undertake major system upgrades or implement overall plans for modernizing their information systems, with states typically investing more than the required 10% match.
</summary>

<summary>

• MWDs (Military Working Dogs) are canines used by the DOD for various operations such as explosive and illegal narcotic detection, patrol, and tracking. They can be adopted after their service, with priority given to former handlers, followed by others capable of caring for them and then law enforcement agencies.
• The NDAA for FY 2016 established priorities for the authorized recipients of MWDs removed from service, with MWDs being made available first to former handlers, then to others capable of humanely caring for the MWD, and finally to law enforcement agencies.
• The DOD uses three systems to track different types of information about MWDs, including information related to their removal from service. These systems are WDMS, the Central Repository, and ROVR.
• Over the past 5 years, the number of MWDs adopted or transferred varied, with the highest numbers in 2012 and 2013. The number of euthanized MWDs varied to a lesser extent.
• Prevalent medical conditions among adopted MWDs include skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues. The most prevalent medical conditions are skin conditions or ear infections, dental disease or injury, arthritis or degenerative joint disease, and degenerative lumbo-sacral stenosis.
• Assistance with privately provided veterinary care is available through nonprofit organizations such as the U.S. War Dogs Association and the American Humane organization.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Food Stamp Program, overseen by the Food and Nutrition Service (FNS), provides assistance to eligible low-income households for food purchases. FNS regulates eligibility, benefit calculation, and reporting requirements, while states implement the program and determine household eligibility based on income and asset limits.
- FNS has introduced options and waivers to increase program access, reduce reporting burden, and minimize payment errors. These include adjustments to eligibility, reporting requirements, extending benefits to households leaving TANF, and options related to TANF recipients. States can also use options to allow households to own vehicles worth more than the allowed amount and remain eligible for food stamp benefits.
- To monitor program performance, FNS measures states' accuracy in determining eligibility and calculating benefits through a quality control system. States face penalties if their payment error rate is higher than the national average. Payment errors can be caused by inadvertent or intentional errors made by recipients or caseworkers, with about half of all errors due to incorrect income determination.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program in 1980 to clean up the nation's most hazardous waste sites.
* EPA investigates contaminated areas and places the most highly contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup, with 1,210 sites on the NPL as of December 1996.
* EPA selects incineration as a Superfund cleanup remedy in about 6% of decisions, using it at three sites at the time of the review and planning to use it at four additional sites.
* Incineration involves four basic steps: preparing and feeding wastes into the incinerator, burning the wastes, collecting and removing ash, and cooling and filtering gases before release.
* Incinerators at Superfund sites are generally "transportable" and constructed and operated by contractors, with CERCLA exempting them from permit requirements but requiring compliance with RCRA's substantive requirements.
* EPA uses four principal methods to ensure the safe operation of incinerators: setting site-specific standards, incorporating safety features, monitoring emissions, and providing 24-hour on-site oversight.
* EPA establishes specific cleanup standards for each incinerator based on studies of the site's characteristics, typically applying RCRA's standards for emissions and operating parameters.
* EPA requires engineering controls and automatic waste feed cutoffs to prevent standards from being exceeded, with additional safety measures at some sites to prevent excessive emissions in the event of an emergency shutdown.
* EPA continuously monitors the air in the vicinity of an incinerator and relies on Corps of Engineers or state officials for on-site oversight, with 24-hour oversight not required by regulations or formal EPA policy.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Comanche helicopter program, established in 1983, aimed to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter for armed reconnaissance and attack missions.
- The program faced funding cuts and restructuring, leading to a delay in the development phase by 3 years, reduced funding, and the production of two flyable prototypes. The Army proposed acquiring six additional aircraft within the Secretary's funding constraint by deferring developmental efforts.
- The restructured program has a high degree of concurrency, meaning production decisions will be made before significant initial operational test and evaluation is completed, increasing the risk of retrofitting production items and inadequate system design testing.
- The Comanche program has experienced significant increases in program acquisition unit cost since 1985, from $12.1 million per aircraft to $34.4 million per aircraft, primarily due to funding reductions and restructuring.
- Software development and maintainability issues increase the risk that the aircraft will not perform successfully. The Comanche will be the most computerized, software-intensive Army helicopter ever built, with about 1.4 million lines of code required for mission critical functions.
- Configuration management challenges and maintainability requirements, such as direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation, put lower operating and support costs and wartime availability goals at risk.
- The Army plans to start operational testing with six helicopters by about August 2005, under the restructured program, which provides sufficient time and aircraft to operationally test the Comanche prior to making any production decisions.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with 10% of them in EAS positions. The Service's diversity development program was created to provide equal employment opportunities and take advantage of its diverse workforce. A study by Aguirre International in 1997 found that the Service was a leader in meeting affirmative action goals and striving for parity between its workforce and the CLF, but women and minorities appeared to be experiencing problems advancing to management jobs at EAS 17 and above positions.

• The representation of women and minorities in EAS 17 and above positions generally increased from fiscal year 1993 to 1997, but black men's representation decreased slightly. White and Hispanic women, Native American men and women, and white men were underrepresented in the Service's cluster-level workforce compared with their representation in the CLF. Similar underrepresentation was found in the Service's headquarters-level and area office-level workforces.

• The Aguirre report found that a glass ceiling existed at positions beginning at EAS 17 for women and minorities, but the report did not explicitly define the term or present convincing supporting evidence. The Service contracted with Aguirre International to study the Service’s diversity program and assess its progress in meeting its goal of creating a Service workforce as diverse as the CLF.

• The Aguirre report used multiple research methods, including data analyses, policy reviews, and employee surveys, to research eight research areas.
