* The 1992 Act also requires the establishment of a title information system to enable states and other users to instantly and reliably determine the validity of title documents, whether an automobile is titled in a particular state, and whether an automobile titled in a particular state is junked or salvaged.
* The implementation of the marking and information systems parts of the 1992 Act faces several issues, including the need for uniformity, funding for the states, responsibility for the titling system, and states' willingness to participate.
* The 1992 Act requires Transportation to establish a task force by April 25, 1993, to study problems related to motor vehicle titling, registration, and salvage, and to recommend ways to solve these problems and other needed legislative or administrative actions.
* The task force recommended, among other things, the passage of federal legislation that would require uniform definitions for terms such as salvage vehicles and uniform methods for titling vehicles, possible funding sources to pay for and maintain the titling system, and penalties to enforce compliance by the participating states.

</summary>

<summary>

• Hate crimes are criminal offenses motivated by bias against certain personal characteristics.
• Federal laws such as the Civil Rights Act of 1968, the Hate Crimes Statistics Act of 1990, and the Hate Crimes Sentencing Enhancement Act of 1994 address hate crimes.
• The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009 expands the definition of hate crimes to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.
• There are questions about the constitutionality of expanding hate crime legislation under the commerce clause due to the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Morrison.
• The legislative clauses of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments give Congress the power to enforce the Amendments by appropriate legislation.
• Section 5 of the 14th Amendment authorizes legislation against state action that denies equal protection or due process, but not against private individuals.
• Section 2 of the 13th Amendment may be a more viable option for broadening hate crime legislation, but it is unclear if violence based on bigotry constitutes a "badge and/or incident of slavery."
• Constitutional challenges to state hate crime statutes have been raised under the 1st and 6th Amendments, which protect freedom of speech and the right to a jury trial, respectively.

</summary>

<summary>

* Reforming or limiting itemized tax deductions for individuals is a topic of interest for policymakers to increase federal tax revenue, shift the tax burden to higher-income filers, simplify the tax code, or reduce inefficient economic behavior.
* In 2014, 30% of tax filers itemized their deductions, with higher-income filers more likely to itemize and claim larger deductions. The majority of itemizers had an AGI less than $100,000, but tax filers with an AGI over $1 million claimed 13.1% of all itemized deductions.
* Common itemized deductions include charitable gifts, state and local income taxes, real estate property taxes, and home mortgage interest. Deductions for charitable gifts and mortgage interest are claimed more frequently by higher-income filers, while medical and dental expenses are claimed less frequently.
* The mortgage interest deduction is the largest deduction for tax filers with an AGI less than $500,000, while state and local income taxes and charitable contributions comprise larger shares of deductions for higher-income filers.

</summary>

<summary>

• The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has changed multiple times throughout history, with some legislative changes attempting to reestablish symmetry between the two. Under current law, asymmetries remain, such as the deductibility of net long-term losses against net short-term gains without limit, and the different tax rates for ordinary income, short-term gains, and long-term gains. The loss limitation was originally enacted to prevent taxpayers from minimizing their income taxes by altering the timing of the realization of gains and losses.

• Increasing the net capital loss limitation to soften the impact of the stock market downturn on some investors may increase the dichotomy between the tax treatment of gains and losses. The cost to the taxpayer of forgoing the full loss in the current year is the interest that would have been earned on the additional tax reduction that would have been realized had there been no excess loss limitation. The current system, even without indexing the $3,000 loss for inflation, is more generous than the system that existed in 1978.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Endangered Species Act (ESA) is a federal law that provides for the listing and protection of species threatened with extinction. It requires federal agencies to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service or the National Marine Fisheries Service to determine if an agency project might jeopardize the existence of listed species or destroy critical habitat.
* The ESA includes a process for federal agencies to seek exemptions from the act's requirements under certain circumstances, but this process is rarely used and has only been granted twice in the four decades since the ESA was enacted.
* The exemption process allows for the consideration of extraordinary economic circumstances and provides an opportunity for economic factors to override jeopardy to the species, but it is for a federal project, license, or action rather than for a species.
* The Endangered Species Committee (ESC) is responsible for reviewing applications for exemptions and determining whether to grant them. The ESC is composed of top government officials and one individual from each affected state.
* The exemption process is complex and can take up to 280 days, and even if an exemption is granted, the applicant is responsible for carrying out and paying for any required mitigation measures.

</summary>

<summary>

• East Asian nations, including China, Japan, and South Korea, have had exchange rate policies that have caused tension with the United States. Some argue these policies are instances of "currency manipulation" and violate international agreements.

• The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires the Department of the Treasury to analyze the exchange rate policies of major trading partners. In its most recent report, it found that no major trading partner met all three criteria for being labeled a currency manipulator. However, China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan were placed on a "Monitoring List."

• There are various types of exchange rate policies that countries can adopt, ranging from a "free float" where the value of a currency is determined by market forces, to a "pegged" exchange rate where a country fixes the value of its currency to another currency or a basket of currencies. Many East Asian governments have chosen a "managed float" policy, which allows for some flexibility while also giving governments more control.

• A "free float" policy has advantages, such as allowing a country more autonomy with its domestic monetary policy, but it also has disadvantages, such as greater exchange-rate risk and potential instability. A "pegged" exchange rate policy eliminates exchange-rate risk but can lead to a loss of autonomy in domestic monetary policy and potential vulnerability to speculative attacks.

• The United States has required biannual reports on the exchange rate policies of foreign countries since the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988. The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 expanded these reporting requirements.

• The Currency Reform for Fair Trade Act, currently being considered in Congress, would allow for the imposition of countervailing duties on imports from countries with "fundamentally undervalued" currencies.

</summary>

<summary>

- China's economy is heavily dependent on global trade and investment, with exports and FDI playing significant roles in its growth.
- The current global economic slowdown, particularly in major export markets, has negatively impacted China's export sector and overall economic growth, with GDP growth slowing down in 2008 and 2009.
- China's exposure to the global financial crisis, particularly from the fallout of the U.S. subprime mortgage problem, is unclear, but Chinese government entities may have been more exposed to troubled U.S. mortgage securities than private sector firms and individual investors.
- China has implemented a 4 trillion yuan ($586 billion) stimulus package to boost infrastructure projects, increase consumer spending, and support certain industries, among other measures.
- The Chinese government plans to create a universal health care system, boost rural incomes and spending levels, and narrow the gap in living standards between rural and urban citizens.
- Despite recent positive developments, there are concerns over long-term growth prospects, including the reliance on bank lending and infrastructure spending, potential increases in non-performing loans, and the impact of stimulus policies on further economic reforms.
- China's role in responding to the global financial crisis is debated, with some suggesting that China may increase investments in U.S. assets to help stabilize the U.S. economy, while others question the wisdom of investing in U.S. government securities and the potential implications of such investments.
- The global financial crisis has affected U.S.-Chinese economic ties, with China blaming U.S. economic policies for the crisis and increasing its use of subsidies, "buy China" regulations, and trade and investment barriers.

</summary>

<summary>

* The title "Chief of Mission" (COM) refers to the principal officer in charge of each U.S. diplomatic mission to a foreign country, foreign territory, or international organization, usually an ambassador.
* The COM is appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, and serves as the President's personal representative, leading diplomatic efforts in the country of assignment under the general supervision of the Secretary of State.
* The role of the COM has expanded since World War II, now overseeing nearly all U.S. government activities in their country of assignment, with the primary exception of military operations.
* COMs exercise this authority through their leadership of the embassy's "country team," which includes the chief representative of each U.S. government agency undertaking activities in the host country.
* The Foreign Service Act of 1980 (FSA 1980) outlines the authorities and responsibilities of COMs, including their responsibilities, authority over personnel, and obligations of U.S. government personnel to the COM.
* COM authority derives originally from the President's general constitutional powers in foreign affairs, and is of greater significance in determining a COM's authority than the pertinent legislative provisions.
* COMs have full responsibility for the direction, coordination, and supervision of all Government executive branch employees in their country, except for Voice of America correspondents and employees under the command of a U.S. Geographic Combatant Commander.
* COMs are responsible for promoting United States goods and services for export to their country of assignment, and for keeping fully and currently informed with respect to all activities and operations of the Government within that country.
* COM authority extends to all DOD personnel in a country except those under the command of a GCC, and COMs are charged with responsibility for the activities of in-country military personnel by a variety of statutes, presidential directives, and executive branch arrangements.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Pacific Islands region is strategically important and includes U.S. territories, as well as countries that have attracted Chinese diplomatic and economic attention. Congress plays a key role in approving and overseeing the Compacts of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The region faces economic, political, and environmental challenges, and the U.S. has economic interests and provides foreign assistance there.

• The Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) and the Melanesian Spearhead Group (MSG) are regional organizations that address issues such as climate change, regional security, and fisheries. The U.S. has observer status with the PIF and friendly relations with Pacific Island countries, including the Freely Associated States. The U.S. has worked with Australia and New Zealand to advance shared strategic interests and promote economic development in the region.

• China has become a diplomatic force, major source of foreign aid, and leading trade partner in the Southwest Pacific, and other nations such as Russia, India, and Indonesia have also increased their engagement in the region. The Pacific Islands can be divided into spheres of influence, including those of the U.S., Australia, New Zealand, and France.

• The U.S. government administers foreign assistance to Pacific Island countries through USAID and has partnered with regional organizations to address climate change. U.S. assistance aims to promote sustainable economic development, good governance, and regional organizations, as well as to cooperate with Australia and regional aid donors on areas of concern and cooperation such as combating illegal fishing, supporting peacekeeping operations, and responding to natural disasters.
</summary>

<summary>

* Banks play a crucial role in the economy by connecting borrowers and savers, but banking is a risky activity that can generate significant losses during banking panics and failures.
* A regulatory system has developed over time to foster the benefits of banking while limiting risks, with both banks and regulation coevolving as market conditions change.
* Recent years have been transformative for banking, with the 2008-2009 financial crisis threatening the total collapse of the financial system and the real economy.
* Congress has enacted various policies in response to the crisis, including the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act and the Basel III Accords, to strengthen regulation and address risks.
* However, some observers have raised concerns that the potential benefits of these regulatory changes may be outweighed by the potential costs, including reduced credit availability and slower economic growth.
</summary>

<summary>

* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through representatives of their own choosing.
* The NLRA applies only to "employees," and the term "supervisor" is defined to include any individual with the authority to perform certain functions with the use of independent judgment.
* In the case of Kentucky River Community Care, Inc., the U.S. Supreme Court maintained that it was inappropriate for the NLRB to characterize judgment that reflects "ordinary professional or technical judgment" as failing to be independent judgment.
* The NLRB has the discretion to clarify the meaning of the term "independent judgment," but the Court believed that the NLRB's reference to "ordinary or technical judgment" established a "startling categorical exclusion."
* In Oakwood Healthcare, Inc., the NLRB interpreted the terms "assign," "responsibly to direct," and "independent judgment" as they are used in section 2(11) of the NLRA.
* The NLRB concluded that 12 permanent charge nurses assigned to five of the 10 patient care units were supervisors for purposes of the NLRA.
* The NLRA prohibits certain misconduct by both employers and unions that interferes with the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining.
* The NLRB has maintained that an employer may make anti-union, but noncoercive, speeches to their employees on company time and on company property without allowing a union an equal opportunity to reply.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is responsible for managing most federal mineral development, including oil and gas leasing on public domain lands. Different statutes apply to public domain lands and acquired lands.
• The Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920 (MLLA) authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to lease oil and gas deposits and onshore public domain lands containing oil and gas deposits, with the federal government retaining title to the lands. This leasing authority applies to National Forest System (NFS) lands that are reserved from the public domain and most reserved subsurface mineral estates.
• The Secretary of the Interior cannot issue any lease for National Forest System lands reserved from the public domain if the Secretary of Agriculture objects. The U.S. Forest Service has issued separate regulations governing certain aspects of leasing and permitting for oil and gas development on lands within its jurisdiction.
• The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (FLPMA) requires the Secretary of the Interior to develop and revise land use plans (RMPs) for public lands managed by BLM, which serve as the initial determinant of which lands may be subject to leasing. All activities performed on these lands must be consistent with the RMPs.
• The Forest Service also manages its lands under multiple use and sustained yield policies, and develops land management plans for NFS lands by considering the desired conditions, objectives, suitability of areas for various uses, and other criteria.
• The MLLA authorizes both competitive and noncompetitive leasing procedures. Competitive bidding must be held on a quarterly basis in each state where public lands are available for leasing, and the Secretary may also authorize additional opportunities for bidding if he considers them to be necessary.
• General restrictions on leasing include limitations on who can lease (U.S. citizens, associations of U.S. citizens, corporations organized under U.S. laws or the laws of any State, and municipalities) and how much land they can lease (no entity is permitted to own or control oil or gas leases in excess of 246,080 acres in any one State other than Alaska).

</summary>

<summary>

- The House of Representatives has rules that govern the procedures and operations of its committees and subcommittees, which are required to adopt their own written rules that comply with House rules. These rules cover various aspects of committee activities, including hearings, markups, reporting, oversight and investigations, funding, staff, and travel. The House Parliamentarian provides guidance on the application of these rules in practice.
- Committee records are the property of the House and are preserved at the National Archives and Records Administration. The Archivist makes archived records publicly available after 30 years, with certain exceptions for investigative records, personnel records, and records of closed hearings, which are made available after 50 years. A committee may temporarily withdraw a record from the Archives for official use, and each committee is required to establish standards for the availability of its archived records.

</summary>

<summary>

- The "state sponsors of terrorism list" is maintained under various provisions of law, and includes Cuba, Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.
* Countries on the list are subject to restrictions on trade benefits, foreign aid, international financial institution support, and other benefits.
* Validated licenses are required for exports to these countries, except for items specifically allowed by public law.
* Cuba's retention on the list has received attention due to initiatives to lift some U.S. economic sanctions, but various trade and aid restrictions would remain in place.
* Cuba was added to the list in 1982 due to its ties to international terrorism, including support for armed insurgencies and terrorist activities in Latin America and the Caribbean.
* Cuba has been accused of providing support for terrorist organizations, including the FALN, FMLN, and FSLN, and of transshipping Soviet arms to Nicaragua and El Salvador for use by terrorist organizations.
* Cuba has been criticized for hosting members of foreign terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives from justice, and for providing safe haven for members of several Foreign Terrorist Organizations.
* Critics argue that Cuba's presence on the list is a holdover of the Cold War, and that it diverts U.S. attention from serious terrorist threats.

</summary>

<summary>

* The President signed S. 2499, the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007, which makes changes to Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP programs.
* The Act suspends the Medicare physician payment cut scheduled to take effect and provides SCHIP funding through March 2009.
* The Act mandates a 0.5% increase in the Medicare physician fee schedule for the six-month period from January 1, 2008, through June 30, 2008, and provides FY2008 and FY2009 SCHIP allotments through March 31, 2009.
* The Act extends a number of expiring provisions and programs, including Medicare payments for certain providers and services, and certain Medicaid payments and programs.
* The Act includes funding for some miscellaneous activities, such as providing additional funds under the State Health Insurance Assistance Programs and making grants for Area Agencies on Aging and Aging and Disability Resource Centers.
* The Act extends the Title V Abstinence Education block grant through June 30, 2008, and amends the Public Health Service Act to provide for research into the prevention of Type I diabetes.
* The Act includes offsets to pay for the aforementioned provisions, such as a reduction in federal payments for the Medicare Advantage stabilization fund in 2012 and strengthened procedures for determining Medicare's responsibility as a secondary payer.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees in the House and Senate are responsible for drafting bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT), the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and six related agencies. The majority of DOT's budget is in the form of contract authority, while most of HUD's programs are designed to address housing problems faced by low-income households or those with special needs.

• The THUD appropriations bill is divided into four titles: Title I funds DOT, Title II funds HUD, Title III funds a collection of transportation and housing-related agencies, and Title IV sets out general provisions applicable to the bill. Most of the programs and activities in the bill are funded through regular annual appropriations, also referred to as discretionary appropriations.

• The President's FY2018 budget requested $106.65 billion for the programs in the THUD bill, a reduction of $9.7 billion from the FY2017 level. The House-passed bill would provide $115.3 billion, and the Senate-reported bill recommended $119.1 billion, representing reductions of roughly 3% and an increase of just over 2% in real funding, respectively, compared to FY2017.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a 10-member grouping of nations in Southeast Asia with a combined population of 580 million and an annual gross domestic product (GDP) of around $1.5 trillion.
* The Obama Administration has expressed an intent to pay greater attention to Southeast Asia, listen more carefully to regional concerns, and work with multilateral organizations, particularly ASEAN, to cooperate on issues of mutual interest.
* The United States has deep-seated interests in Southeast Asia, including maritime security, the promotion of democracy and human rights, the encouragement of liberal trade and investment regimes, counterterrorism, and the combating of illegal trafficking of narcotics and human trafficking.
* Engagement with ASEAN has presented the United States with a foreign policy dilemma, as some analysts believe the region has become an important site of "soft power" rivalry between the United States and China.
* Despite considerable U.S. security, economic, and foreign assistance initiatives in the region, particularly at the bilateral level, in recent years a perception has developed among Southeast Asian elites that the United States has placed relatively little priority on ASEAN itself and has, thereby, demonstrated a lack of commitment to Southeast Asia as a whole.
* The United States has long had close bilateral relations with many of Southeast Asia's nations, but symbolic commitment is particularly important in a region that places a heavy emphasis on process and informal networking.

</summary>

<summary>

- In 2005, the U.S. and India established a "global partnership" with increased cooperation in various sectors, while India maintained positive relations with Iran, including a "strategic partnership" since 2003.
- Some in Washington are concerned about India's friendship with Iran, fearing it could hinder U.S.-India ties, but New Delhi's relations with Tehran are unlikely to derail the partnership, given India's interest in maintaining ties, especially in energy commerce.
- Indian firms have taken long-term contracts for purchase of Iranian gas and oil, and India supports proposed construction of a pipeline to deliver Iranian natural gas to India through Pakistan, which the U.S. opposes.
- India has historically aligned with the "nonaligned movement" and has friendly links with Tehran, but recent developments show New Delhi intending to bring its Iran policy into closer alignment with that of the United States.
- There have been occasional revelations of Indian transfers to Iran of technology that could be useful for Iran's purported weapons of mass destruction programs, leading to sanctions against some Indian entities.
- India and Iran have established steady but relatively low level defense and military relations, with occasional joint naval exercises, but no major purchases or significant military assistance from India to Iran.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term, including Florida v. Jardines, which dealt with whether a dog sniff at a suspected grow house is a Fourth Amendment search.
* The Court held that it is, based on the "property intrusion" rationale rather than the "expectation of privacy" rationale used in past cases.
* In Jardines, Miami-Dade Police received an anonymous tip about marijuana growing in the house and used a trained drug-detection dog to confirm the presence of drugs, leading to a search warrant and the discovery of marijuana.
* The Florida Supreme Court had previously ruled that a dog sniff is not sufficient to establish probable cause for a search, but the U.S. Supreme Court reversed that decision in Jardines.
* The Court's decision was based on the principle that a Fourth Amendment search occurs when the government physically intrudes on constitutionally protected property, as established in the Jones case.
</summary>

<summary>

• The source discusses the debate over import barriers on milk protein concentrates (MPCs) in the US, which are derived from raw milk and used in various food products, animal feed, and industrial products. Currently, US imports of MPCs have limited or no trade restrictions while many other dairy product imports are restricted by tariff-rate quotas. Advocates argue that stricter import controls on MPCs would encourage the use of domestically produced protein and raise milk prices for dairy farmers, while opponents argue that it would increase their costs and result in higher retail food prices. Major foreign suppliers of MPCs to the US market would likely seek compensation under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules for new US restrictions on MPC imports.

• The US produces very little casein or milk protein concentrates, and the federal dairy policies, particularly the Dairy Product Price Support program, have encouraged the production of nonfat dry milk (NDM) at the expense of milk protein concentrate or casein. U.S. imports of dairy products, including MPCs and casein/caseinates, represented 35% of total import value in 2008. Dairy imports are modest relative to domestic production, but constraints on dairy product imports are needed to maintain the integrity of the domestic dairy program. The US dairy program supports prices of dairy products and pays farmers subsidies when milk prices decline below certain levels.

</summary>

<summary>

* In 2000, democratic parties defeated Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic, leading to a transition towards democratic and free market standards.
* Serbia has held largely free and fair elections, but organized crime, high-level corruption, and economic problems persist.
* The European Union (EU) is Serbia's key foreign policy goal, but concerns over Kosovo's independence and U.S. support for it have strained U.S.-Serbian relations.
* The most recent elections in 2012 resulted in the Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) winning the majority of seats, followed by the Democratic Party (DS) and the Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS).
* The new government, led by the SNS and the Socialists, aims to tackle corruption and improve the economy, with Aleksandar Vucic serving as Defense Minister and overseeing intelligence services.
* Serbia's relations with Kosovo, particularly the status of the Serbian-majority municipalities in the north, remain a contentious issue, with the EU and the U.S. pushing for de facto recognition of Kosovo's independence.
* The U.S. has maintained a focus on the Balkans since the 1990s, supporting Serbia's democratic development and regional stability, while also recognizing Kosovo's independence and pressing for Serbia-Kosovo normalization.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is a separate tax calculation with a broader base than the regular tax, including certain business provisions and itemized deductions, but excluding benefits like lower capital gains tax rates and home mortgage interest deductions. The AMT exemptions are not indexed to inflation, causing an increase in the number of taxpayers subject to it.

• The AMT covered 1.0% of tax returns in 1987, but due to inflation and the elimination of the capital gains deduction, it covered 6.0% of tax returns in 1999 and is projected to cover 6.3% in 2009. The AMT would also limit tax credits, such as the child credit and education credits, affecting a larger portion of returns with tax liability.

• The AMT shift from the very highest income classes to the middle and upper middle income classes is dramatic over time, with almost half of AMT taxpayers falling into the 1.6% of tax-filers with adjusted income over $200,000 in 1998, and less than 15% having incomes over $200,000 in 2008.

• The cost of correcting the AMT is significant, with indexing AMT exemptions costing $13.9 billion by 2008, eliminating the credit limit provision costing many billions of dollars by 2008 or 2009, and eliminating the credit limit provision and adding standard deductions costing $26 billion by 2009 and $96 billion for the period 1999-2009.

• Tax cuts, such as those in H.R. 1836, can increase the number of taxpayers on the AMT and cause some or all of the tax cut not to be received by certain families, particularly for joint returns due to progressive tax rates and larger dependents.
</summary>

<summary>

• High risk health insurance pools (HRPs) are established by 35 states to provide health insurance coverage to individuals who cannot obtain or afford coverage in the private market due to preexisting health conditions.
• HRPs are used to comply with HIPAA's portability and guaranteed availability provisions, and are designed to assist individuals with costly medical conditions who have few options for private health coverage.
• State HRPs generally cover people who have been denied coverage or received high quotes in the individual market, and have enrolled approximately 200,000 individuals, although an estimated 4 million additional persons may be eligible.
• Federal and state laws restrict insurers' ability to reject applications or design coverage based on health factors in the nongroup market, but some applicants are still rejected or charged higher premiums.
• HRPs are intended to stabilize the market, promote competition, and retain insurance carriers, but some researchers are skeptical of their ability to substantially reduce the number of uninsured, particularly among those with serious medical conditions.

</summary>

<summary>

- The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is a U.S. Department of Commerce agency that advises on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies, represents the executive branch in telecommunications and information policy activities, and manages spectrum used by federal agencies.
- NTIA's responsibilities include overseeing the transfer of radio frequencies from the federal domain to the commercial domain, administering grants programs, and establishing a new $135 million grant program for states to plan for participation in a nationwide public safety broadband network.
- NTIA collaborates with other agencies, such as the Federal Communications Commission, Department of State, Rural Utilities Service, and Department of Homeland Security, on various telecommunications and information technology issues.
- NTIA is working to increase spectrum capacity for mobile broadband by 500 MHz over the next 10 years, in part by identifying bands of spectrum that might be available for commercial wireless broadband service and preparing for the World Radio Conference in 2015-2016.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) is a program established in 1951, which supports the Department of Defense's (DOD) airlift requirements during emergencies when the need exceeds the capacity of DOD's organic airlift fleet. CRAF participants are primarily expected to transport passengers and cargo pallets.
* CRAF has three main segments: international, national, and aeromedical evacuation. The international segment is further divided into long-range and short-range sections, while the national segment is divided into domestic and Alaskan sections. Assignment of aircraft to a segment depends on the nature of the requirement and the aircraft performance characteristics needed.
* The FY2008 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) contained provisions that affected the CRAF, including a comprehensive and independent assessment of CRAF, extension of authorization of the Aviation Insurance Program (AIP), and a DOD study on the size and mix of the airlift force to specifically include how the CRAF could potentially affect DOD's airlift fleet requirements.

</summary>

<summary>

• The federal government has supported energy storage and electric power system technology since the 1970s, before the establishment of the Department of Energy (DOE).
• The electric power industry faces challenges such as a changing power generation mix, aging infrastructure, modernizing communication networks, accommodating new end-use technologies, and increasing interdependencies of natural gas, water, and electricity systems.
• The DOE Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) is responsible for supporting more economically competitive, environmentally responsible, secure, and resilient U.S. energy infrastructure.
• OE's goal for the future grid is to support economic growth and energy innovation through delivery of reliable, affordable, and clean electricity to consumers where, when, and how they want it.
• The largest share of OE funding goes to R&D on technology development, while the remainder goes to planning and operational areas.
• OE divides its responsibilities into five general areas: R&D and Deployment, Modeling and Analytics, Institutional Support and Technical Assistance, Coordination of Federal Transmission Permits, and Emergency Preparedness and Response.
• OE's mission is guided by two key DOE planning documents: the Quadrennial Technolo gy Review and the Grid Modernization Multi-Year Program Plan.
• OE currently has five deputy assistant secretaries, each of whom reports to the Assistant Secretary, and is responsible for overseeing five offices: Power Systems Engineering R&D, National Electricity Delivery, Infrastructure Security and Energy Restoration, Energy Infrastructure Modeling and Analysis, and Advanced Grid Integration.
• OE programs are aligned with the Obama Administration's priorities, as documented in A Policy Framework for the 21 st Century Grid, the President's Climate Action Plan, and other DOE efforts to address energy infrastructure needs and challenges.

</summary>

• The poverty rate tends to follow the economic cycle, with higher poverty rates during recessions and lower rates during economic growth.

* The creation of commemorative works in the District of Columbia has evolved over time, with the first equestrian statue of George Washington authorized in 1783.
* Prior to 1986, there were no statutory criteria for authorizing commemorative works, and Congress established site locations and approved memorial designs.
* In 1986, Congress passed the Commemorative Works Act (CWA) to guide the memorial creation process in the District of Columbia.
* The CWA established a 24-step process for creating a memorial, including selecting a site, designing the memorial, fundraising, and construction.
* The CWA also defines a commemorative work as a structure or landscape feature designed to perpetuate the memory of an individual, group, event, or other significant element of American history.
* The CWA does not apply to military properties or land under the jurisdiction of the Smithsonian or the Architect of the Capitol.
* The CWA has been amended several times since its enactment, including extending the time allowed for completing a commemorative work and allowing for on-site donor recognition.
* The National Capital Planning Commission and other entities are responsible for ensuring that the comprehensive design of the L'Enfant and McMillan plans for the Nation's Capital is preserved.
* The CWA aims to preserve open space in the District of Columbia, encourage the location of commemorative works within the urban fabric of the city, and ensure that future commemorative works are appropriately designed, constructed, and located.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) was enacted in 1936 to allow small businesses to compete with larger companies in purchasing commodities.
• The R-P prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality," and applies only to the sale of goods purchased for resale within the United States.
• The R-P has been inconsistently enforced by the Federal Trade Commission and has been criticized by the Department of Justice for having adverse effects on the economy.
• Defenses to an allegation of unlawful price differentials under the R-P include "meeting competition" and cost justification, as well as the Nonprofit Institutions Act which permits price breaks for certain nonprofit institutions.
• The Nonprofit Institutions Act has been interpreted strictly by the Supreme Court, limiting its exemption to purchases made for the institution's own use and not for resale or private practice use.
• The Antitrust Modernization Commission recommended in 2007 that Congress should repeal the Robinson-Patman Act in its entirety due to its unintended effect of limiting discounting and causing higher prices for consumers.

</summary>

<summary>

- The report analyzes the FY2017 appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), comparing it with the enacted FY2016 appropriations, the Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, and the Trump Administration's requests for additional funding. It also explains budgetary concepts and terms in the appendix.
- The homeland security appropriations bill includes all annual appropriations provided for DHS, with discretionary appropriations providing roughly two-thirds to three-fourths of the annual funding. The remaining budget is a mix of fee revenues, trust funds, and mandatory spending.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Energy Policy Act of 2005, also known as the "Electric Reliability Act of 2005," includes provisions aimed at improving the reliability of the U.S. bulk power system. It grants the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) authority to establish and regulate an electric reliability organization (ERO), which will develop and enforce reliability standards for the bulk power system, including cybersecurity protection.

• The act requires FERC to conduct a study of electric transmission congestion every three years and authorizes FERC to issue construction permits in designated congested areas, with opportunities for affected parties to present their views and recommendations. It also gives the Department of Energy new authority to prepare environmental documents and make decisions on rights-of-way and siting on federal lands.

• The act includes provisions for third-party financing of transmission facilities and establishes an Advanced Transmission Technologies Deployment Initiative to encourage the deployment of advanced transmission technologies. It also creates an Advanced Power System Technology Incentive Program to provide incentive payments to owners or operators of advanced power generation systems.

• The act includes provisions for open, nondiscriminatory access to transmission facilities for power marketing administrations, state entities, and rural electric cooperatives. It also allows federal utilities to participate in regional transmission organizations and grants the Secretary of Energy new authority to prepare environmental documents and make decisions on rights-of-way and siting on federal lands.

• The act includes provisions for the protection of transmission contracts in the Pacific Northwest and a sense of Congress regarding a proposed locational installed capacity mechanism in New England. It also requires FERC to issue a rule on long-term transmission rights and organized markets and establishes a Public Utility Holding Company Act of 2005.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Senate Finance Committee approved the America's Healthy Future Act of 2009 (S. 1796) on October 13, 2009, which includes restructuring the private health insurance market, setting minimum standards for health benefits, and providing financial assistance to certain individuals and small employers.
* The bill requires individuals to maintain health insurance and imposes a tax on certain employers with more than 50 employees who do not provide insurance. Market reforms include modified community rating, guaranteed issue and renewal, and are linked to essential health benefits coverage.
* Qualifying coverage includes QHBPs offered in or out of an exchange, new group or individual coverage that meets or exceeds minimum health benefits, grandfathered employment-based plans, grandfathered nongroup plans, and other coverage such as Medicare and Medicaid.
* Exchanges would provide eligible individuals and small businesses with access to private plans in a comparable way, and certain individuals with incomes below 400% of the federal poverty level could qualify for credits toward their premium costs and subsidies towards their cost-sharing.
* States would be provided flexibility to establish basic plans for low-income individuals not eligible for Medicaid, and existing plans offered by employers and in the individual market would be grandfathered.
* New plans could be sold in both the individual and group market outside of an exchange, but only those new plans that meet the minimum requirements specified in the bill would satisfy the requirements for individuals and employers.
* Title VI includes a number of provisions to raise revenues to pay for expanded health insurance coverage, including excise taxes and annual fees on health insurers, limitations on executive compensation of insurance companies, and limitations on contributions to tax-advantaged accounts.
* The bill would alter how current private health insurance markets function, primarily for individuals who purchase coverage directly from an insurer or through a small employer, and would require insurers to not exclude potential enrollees or charge them premiums based on pre-existing health conditions.
* The removal of one provision from the bill could be deleterious to the implementation of the others, and the provisions are interrelated and interdependent.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Take Care Clause of the U.S. Constitution requires the President to ensure that laws are faithfully executed.
• The Clause has been interpreted as placing an obligation on the President to comply with and execute clear statutory directives, while also ensuring Presidential control over the enforcement of federal law.
• The Supreme Court has generally not reviewed Presidential enforcement decisions, including the decision of whether to initiate a criminal prosecution or administrative enforcement action in response to a violation of federal law or regulation.
• The President plays a significant role in the legislative process, but once a bill is enacted into law, the President's legislative role comes to an end and is supplanted by the President's obligation to faithfully execute the law.
• The Take Care Clause has been invoked as forming the constitutional basis for both the President's obligation to enforce the law and the President's discretion not to enforce the law.
• The executive branch has acknowledged that it has no inherent constitutional authority to suspend the enforcement of the laws, particularly of statutes.
• The Take Care Clause makes a significant contribution to the separation of powers by operating as a clear demarcation of the legitimate powers and responsibilities of both the President and Congress in our constitutional system.
• The President and executive branch officials may not create law by unilaterally disregarding, amending, or repealing a validly enacted statute.
• The Supreme Court has held that the Take Care Clause imposes a "duty" or "obligation" upon the President to ensure that executive branch officials obey Congress's commands, and that the Clause does not provide the President with the authority to frustrate legal requirements imposed by law.

</summary>

<summary>

* The US agricultural sector heavily relies on exports, accounting for about 20% of total production.
* US farm policy is subject to WTO rules and scrutiny, with farm bills locking in policy behavior for extended periods.
* The Agricultural Act of 2014, the current omnibus farm bill, made significant changes to the previous safety net and will expire in 2018.
* WTO commitments, particularly the AoA and SCM agreements, limit domestic agricultural support and govern trade disputes.
* The AoA categorizes domestic support programs into green, blue, amber, and de minimis boxes based on their potential to distort markets.
* Green box programs are minimally trade-distorting and exempt from spending limits, while amber box programs are most market-distorting and subject to strict limits.
* The US is committed to spending no more than $19.1 billion per year on amber box support, and faces de minimis exclusions based on production value.
* The 2014 farm bill includes a safety trigger to adjust program outlays and avoid breaching the AMS limit, and the US last notified the WTO of its domestic policies in December 2014.

</summary>

<summary>

* The document discusses the issue of adults going missing and the proposed measures to assist in recovering vulnerable adults who go missing, including the House passing legislation (H.R. 632) to establish a grant program for states to establish, expand, and coordinate alert systems for vulnerable adults.
* The Congressional Research Service (CRS) gathered data on existing state alert systems in 11 states and found that these systems were established beginning in 2006 and are administered by local and/or state law enforcement agencies to alert law enforcement entities and/or the public that vulnerable adults are missing and may need assistance.
* The report also provides an overview of the alert systems in 11 states, including the legal authority to establish the systems, target population for the alerts, administrative responsibility for the alerts, training of law enforcement agencies and other entities about the alerts, the process for activating alerts, coordination of alerts with other states, system costs, use of the systems, and any information about outcomes of the individuals who were believed to be lost and for whom alerts were activated.

</summary>

• The United States and New Zealand have re-established a close security partnership, with defense and security cooperation being significantly bolstered. This is evidenced by President Obama's invitation to Prime Minister Key to attend the Nuclear Summit in 2010, the lifting of restrictions on bilateral defense cooperation, and high-level exchanges between the two nations.

• The Wellington Declaration of 2010 and the 2012 Washington Declaration on Defense Cooperation have played key roles in reorienting the bilateral relationship and enabling enhanced strategic dialogue and defense cooperation. The two nations have also been working together in addressing regional and global challenges, including patrolling the Exclusive Economic Zones of Pacific island states and enforcing control of their fisheries.

</summary>

<summary>

- The federal estate tax is a tax on the estate of a deceased person, levied against and paid by the estate, while an inheritance tax is imposed on and paid by the heirs of the decedent. The gross estate includes the value of all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, wherever situated, in which the decedent owned an interest on the date of death, and may also include certain interests in property transferred prior to death.
* The value of property included in the gross estate is generally its fair market value on the date of death, determined by the price at which the estate property would change hands between a willing buyer and seller.
* Deductions from the gross estate include estate administration expenses, certain debts and losses, the amount of qualified transfers to a surviving spouse, charitable bequests, and state death taxes.
* The federal gift tax is a tax imposed on an annual basis on all gratuitous transfers of property made during life, and the taxable gift is determined by reducing the gross value of the gift by the available deductions and exclusions.
* The generation-skipping transfer (GST) tax is a flat-rate tax applied to three different transfer events: a direct skip, a taxable termination, or a taxable distribution, and is calculated based on the value of the property transferred and the inclusion ratio of the transfer.
</summary>

<summary>

• Water infrastructure systems are vulnerable to terrorist attacks, including physical disruption, bioterrorism/chemical contamination, and cyber attacks.
• Damage or destruction could disrupt vital human services, threatening public health and the environment, or causing loss of life.
• Water infrastructure is highly linked with other infrastructure systems, such as electric power and transportation, making security of all of them an issue of concern.
• Water infrastructure systems include surface and ground water sources, dams, reservoirs, aqueducts, pipes, treatment facilities, distribution systems, and wastewater collection and treatment facilities.
• There are approximately 77,000 dams and reservoirs, thousands of miles of pipes, aqueducts, water distribution, and sewer lines, 168,000 public drinking water facilities, and 16,000 publicly owned wastewater treatment facilities in the U.S.
• Ownership and management are both public and private, with the federal government having ownership responsibility for hundreds of dams and diversion structures.
• The federal government has built hundreds of water projects, primarily for irrigation development and flood control, with municipal and industrial water use as an incidental, self-financed, project purpose.
• Water infrastructure system designers, managers, and operators have long made preparing for extreme events a standard practice, but the focus has historically been on natural events rather than manmade threats.
• Following the 9/11 attacks, federal dam operators went on "high-alert" and implemented additional security measures, and local utilities have primary responsibility to assess their vulnerabilities and prioritize security improvements.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Education Act of 1998 (Perkins III) was amended and reauthorized by the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV). Perkins IV authorizes funding for career and technical education for FY2007-FY2012.

• Perkins IV makes changes to funding formulas, accountability requirements, state and local plans and uses of funds, the tech-prep program, and the equitable participation of private school students in career and technical education programs. It also replaces incentive grants with the "State Allotment Formula" and increases direct grants to outlying areas.

• Perkins IV requires states to distribute at least 85% of state grant funds to the local level, with up to 10% reserved for eligible recipients in rural areas and in areas with high percentages or high numbers of career and technical education students. States may reserve up to 5% of their grants for administration of the State plan.

• Perkins IV establishes six explicit core indicators of performance at the secondary level and five core indicators at the postsecondary level. Both eligible agencies and eligible recipients are required to establish measures for each of the indicators.

• Perkins IV includes greater specification of membership on the independent advisory panel and adds additional requirements for the assessment of career and technical education programs, such as examining teacher preparation and qualifications and the integration of rigorous and challenging academic and career and technical education.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG), Federal Work-Study (FWS), and Federal Perkins Loan programs are collectively referred to as the "campus-based" programs, which are authorized under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA).
• These programs are unique as federal funds are awarded directly to institutions of higher education (IHEs) that administer the programs and provide institutional funds to match the federal funds they receive.
• The campus-based programs have come to play a relatively smaller role in the federal student aid effort, with only 2% of the approximately $125 billion of federal aid made available to students in FY2016 going to these programs.
• The FWS and FSEOG programs have continued to be funded through annual appropriation bills, while the Perkins Loan program was amended and extended through FY2017 under the Federal Perkins Loan Program Extension Act of 2015.
• The campus-based programs were among the first of the federally funded student aid programs, each designed to increase access to higher education for students who demonstrated financial need.
• The Federal Perkins Loan program, the oldest of the campus-based aid programs, was originally enacted under Title II of the National Defense Education Act of 1958 and authorized participating IHEs to award low-interest rate loans to students with financial need.
• The FWS program was originally authorized as the College Work Study program under the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964 to stimulate and promote the part-time employment of students in institutions of higher education who are from low-income families.
• The FSEOG program, authorized as the Education Opportunity Grants under the HEA, was extended and renamed as the FSEOG program in 1972 to serve as a supplement to the Basic Educational Opportunity Grant program.
• The allocation formula for the campus-based programs is based on a two-stage, state distribution formula, with funds first allocated to each state based on the population of students in the state and then sub-allocated to IHEs within the state based on the financial need of the IHE's students.
</summary>

<summary>

* The expedited removal process is a streamlined procedure for removing certain inadmissible aliens from the United States without a hearing or further review, unless they express an intent to apply for asylum or a fear of persecution.
* The process applies to arriving aliens seeking entry into the United States at a designated port of entry, aliens who arrived in the United States by sea and have not been admitted or paroled and have been in the country for less than two years, and aliens who are encountered within 100 miles of the border and have not been admitted or paroled and have been in the United States for less than 14 days.
* Aliens who are charged with being inadmissible under certain grounds, such as lacking valid entry documents or attempting to procure admission through fraud or misrepresentation, may be subject to expedited removal.
* The expedited removal process is a major component of immigration enforcement and has been regularly employed by immigration authorities to remove persons from the United States.
</summary>

<summary>

- Cabo Verde is a small island nation with historical ties to the United States, located off the coast of West Africa.
- It is strategically significant due to its location as a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe and a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic.
- U.S.-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects.
- Cabo Verde is a democratic country with high per capita income levels, a high literacy rate, and positive social indicators.
- It has few natural resources and faces challenges such as water shortages, recurrent droughts, and unequal access to economic opportunities.
- Cabo Verde's economy is classified as lower-middle-income and it has a high literacy rate and generally high social services and health indicators.
- The country has received substantial U.S. development assistance under two MCC Compacts and engages in bilateral security cooperation with the United States and European partners.
- Cabo Verde's main transnational security challenges relate to illicit narcotics transshipment, and it has a small national military and is an active member of the Economic Community of West African States.
- U.S.-Cabo Verdean relations have traditionally been friendly, and the country has received limited U.S. security aid and engages in counternarcotics and related maritime security efforts.

</summary>

- The Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition, including funding for training and reemployment services, income support, and a tax credit for health insurance premiums.
- TAA was reauthorized by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA) and is jointly administered by the U.S. Department of Labor and state agencies. It is funded by mandatory appropriations, which are subject to sequestration.

• The U.S. Constitution's Recess Appointments Clause allows the President to appoint officers during the recess of the Senate.
• The clause has been a source of tension between the executive and legislative branches throughout history.
• President Obama faced difficulty obtaining Senate confirmation for nominations to the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (CFPB) and the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB).
• The NLRB had vacancies during the presidencies of George W. Bush and Obama, including a period of over two years with only two members.
• In 2010, the Supreme Court ruled that the NLRB cannot exercise rulemaking powers without three or more members.
• In 2011, President Obama nominated Richard Cordray as CFPB Director and Terrence F. Flynn, Sharon Block, and Richard F. Griffin Jr. as NLRB members.
• The Senate did not confirm the NLRB nominees before the third member's term expired, leading President Obama to consider recess appointments.
• The Senate held pro forma sessions to prevent recess appointments, which are governed by unanimous consent agreements prohibiting formal business.
• On January 4, 2012, President Obama made recess appointments to the CFPB and NLRB during a three-day recess between pro forma sessions.
• The appointments have been contentious, raising legal questions about the scope of the President's authority and the statutory authorities of the appointees.

</summary>

<summary>

- Severe fire seasons have led to proposals and enactment of new fire protection programs and funding, including the National Fire Plan, Healthy Forests Restoration Act, and FLAME Act.
- Federal wildfire funding has increased since 2000, now constituting a significant portion of land management agency budgets, with total wildfire funding for FY2008 reaching a record $4.46 billion.
- Federal wildfire programs are categorized into protection of federal lands, protection of non-federal lands, and fire research and facility improvements.
- The U.S. Forest Service (FS), created in 1905, initially focused on halting wildfires in national forests, with aggressive fire control policies that evolved over time.
- Concerns about fuel loads and catastrophic fires led to changes in federal fire policy, with equal priority given to private property and federal resources since 1995.
- Wildfire costs have been a topic of interest, with pending legislation addressing issues such as cost-sharing and accountability.
- Federal land fire management appropriations have risen since 1999, with fluctuations primarily depending on the severity of the preceding fire season.

</summary>

<summary>

* Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a critical function in protecting the American people from terrorists and their weapons.
* The federal government has implemented multiple programs and policies to achieve BTS, which can be seen as a series of concentric circles or screens starting from preventive efforts launched outside the country and moving through progressively smaller circles.
* Congressional concern with terrorism and border security has been manifested through a series of commissions and legislative measures, starting in 1998 and continuing through the present day.
* The Homeland Security Act of 2002 consolidated many federal agencies responsible for border and transportation security into the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), which includes the Directorate of BTS, the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection (CBP), the Transportation Security Agency (TSA), and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
* CBP is responsible for securing U.S. borders while facilitating the flow of people and goods, and works in tandem with the U.S. Coast Guard at sea ports of entry to prevent harmful things from entering the country.
* The U.S. maritime system consists of more than 300 sea and river ports with more than 3,700 cargo and passenger terminals, and contains many potential vulnerabilities that are being addressed through various security measures.
* The U.S. government has employed a number of strategies and programs to make the nation's borders more secure, including pushing the border outwards, hardening the border, making the border more accessible for legitimate trade and travel, strengthening the border through more effective use of intelligence, and multiplying effectiveness through the engagement of other actors in the enforcement effort.
* Current border security policies may reflect an attempt at layering, with efforts to preempt potential attacks, prevent individuals from entering the country illegally, harden the border through the use of technology, and engage other actors such as state and local law enforcement and foreign neighbors.
* The current programs and policies in place to achieve BTS were either put into place as a result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks or predated the attacks, and some contend that there are still gaps in the system.
</summary>

<summary>

* The principle of a republic is that the people should choose whom they please to govern them, as embodied in congressional redistricting.
* Prior to the 1960s, court challenges to redistricting plans were considered non-justiciable political questions, but the Supreme Court held in Baker v. Carr that a constitutional challenge to a redistricting plan was not a political question and was justiciable.
* Recent and pending Supreme Court cases have significantly shaped how congressional districts are drawn and the degree to which challenges to redistricting plans will be successful.
* Key constitutional and federal statutory requirements applicable to congressional redistricting include the standard for equality of population among districts and the Voting Rights Act (VRA).
* Case law interpreting the constitutional requirement of congressional district equality, including the "one person, one vote" standard, has explored the degree to which districts must be drawn to achieve exact population equality.
* The Supreme Court has clarified how a court should evaluate whether race was a predominant factor in the development of a redistricting plan and upheld, under the Elections Clause, an Arizona constitutional provision establishing an independent commission for drawing congressional districts.
* The Court has ruled that states may draw their legislative districts based on total population rather than based on eligible or registered voters and is considering cases regarding partisanship and race in redistricting.
* The report discusses the application of Section 2 of the VRA to congressional redistricting, and relatedly, limits to VRA compliance under the Fourteenth Amendment.
* The report also addresses the Court's 2015 ruling upholding an Arizona constitutional provision establishing an independent commission for drawing congressional districts and provides an overview of selected legislation in the 114th Congress related to congressional redistricting.

</summary>

- About 27.5% of state and local government employees in the US (around 6.6 million people) do not have Social Security coverage, with considerable variation across states.
- Congress made Social Security coverage mandatory for most state and local government employees hired after July 1991 who were not already covered, with some exceptions for those with public pension plans.
- Social Security coverage for public employees is extended through "Section 218 Agreements" between states and the Social Security Administration, with each state having a designated State Social Security Administrator.
- Coverage under Section 218 Agreements differs by state and even by county, and once provided, it generally cannot be terminated for future employees in covered positions.
- Proposals to mandate Social Security coverage for all newly hired state and local government employees have been discussed for many years.
- The Bipartisan Policy Center and the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform have recommended mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees, starting in 2020 and 2021, respectively.
- The Social Security Trust Funds are projected to face long-term funding shortfalls, and mandatory coverage for newly hired state and local government employees could help alleviate some of these issues.
- Opponents of mandatory coverage argue that it might not result in better benefit protections for workers, as state and local governments could reduce some pension benefits, and Congress could change Social Security contribution and benefit structures.

</summary>

- The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) requires meat packers to report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, and other products to the USDA. The act was reauthorized until September 30, 2020, with provisions to improve the program's effectiveness and efficiency.
- Mandatory reporting was enacted in 1999 to address issues with the USDA's voluntary price-reporting program, which was not reporting a significant portion of transactions. The LMR was intended to provide accurate and objective market information to all buyers and sellers.

- Burma is a major source of transnational crime, including drug trafficking, human trafficking, and illegal trade in gems, timber, and wildlife, with an estimated value of several billion dollars annually.
- Corruption among Burmese officials, particularly in the military and border areas, facilitates these activities and provides immunity from law enforcement.
- The physical terrain and ethnic tensions in Burma's border regions contribute to the difficulty in controlling transnational crime.
- The United States has imposed sanctions on Burma for its role in transnational crime, including the Tom Lantos Block Burmese JADE Act of 2008, and has designated Burma as a Tier 3 state in the Trafficking in Persons Report.
- The UWSA, Shan State Army-South, Shan State Army-North, Democratic Karen Buddhist Army, and other armed groups have criminal networks that stretch across several countries, including India, China, and Malaysia.

• In 2008, an unknown programmer or group of programmers using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto created Bitcoin, the first known cryptocurrency, which is a digital payment system that uses cryptographic protocols instead of a centralized intermediary.
• Cryptocurrencies have gone from little-known curiosities to rapidly proliferating financial instruments, used in a variety of financial transactions and products, and have been the subject of intense public interest.
• When analyzing the public policy implications of cryptocurrencies, it is important to understand that they are expressly designed and intended to be alternative electronic payment systems.
• Money exists to facilitate the exchange of goods and services, and how well something serves as money depends on how well it serves as a medium of exchange, a unit of account, and a store of value.
• Cryptocurrencies have the potential to offer benefits such as increased efficiency, privacy, and independence from centralized institutions and authorities, but they also face challenges such as lack of widespread adoption, technological challenges, and obstacles to becoming a valuable, widely used form of money.
• Policymakers may be faced with various issues related to cryptocurrency, including concerns about its alleged facilitation of crime, the adequacy of consumer protections, the level of appropriate regulation, and cryptocurrency's potential effect on monetary policy.

</summary>

• The United States has approximately 766 million acres of forestlands, mostly privately owned. The federal government supports forest management on private and public forests through various programs, primarily administered by the Forest Service (FS) in the USDA. These programs aim to achieve forest management and protection goals, including wildfire planning and response, and developing wood products markets.

• Forestry assistance programs have been a part of USDA's initiatives for over a century, with the creation of the USDA Division of Forestry in 1881. The FS, established in 1905, has three main mission areas: managing the National Forest System, conducting forestry research, and providing forestry assistance. The Senate and House Agriculture Committees oversee forestry-related programs.

• State Forest Action Plans are required for states to receive funds for most programs. These plans involve statewide assessments of forest resource conditions, identification of threats, and long-term strategies for addressing issues. The FS provides technical and financial assistance to states, who then help private landowners and eligible entities.

• Funding for forestry assistance programs has declined over the past 15 years. Most programs are available nationally, have permanently authorized funding, and are funded through the annual discretionary appropriations process. The Administration requested $197.4 million for FY2019, a decrease from the FY2018 funding level.

The funding level Congress decides for FY2018 could impact EERE goals and priorities.

- A sitting Member of the United States Senate is not directly affected by any federal statute, constitutional provision, or Rule of the Senate if indicted for a felony, and does not forfeit their office upon conviction of a felony unless it is for certain treasonous conduct committed after taking an oath of office.
* Indictment or conviction of a felony does not constitutionally disqualify one from being a Member of Congress, unless it is for certain treasonous conduct committed after taking an oath of office.
* The Senate Republican Conference Rules have required an indicted chairman or ranking Member of a Senate committee, or a member of the Senate party leadership, to temporarily step aside from his or her leadership or chairmanship position.
* Conviction of certain crimes may subject Senators to internal legislative disciplinary proceedings, including resolutions of censure, and expulsion from the Senate upon approval of two-thirds of the Members.
* Expulsion of a Member from Congress does not result in the forfeiture or loss of one’s federal pension, but the Member’s conviction of certain crimes may lead to such forfeiture of retirement annuities.
* The Senate has historically waited to impose congressional discipline, such as expulsion or censure against a Member, until the question of guilt has been at least initially resolved through the judicial system.
* The Senate has taken a broad view of its authority to censure or otherwise discipline its Members for any conduct that the Senate finds to be reprehensible and/or to reflect discredit on the institution.

</summary>

• Foreign doctorates are employed in large numbers by industry, and many foreign students use US graduate education programs as stepping stones to immigration.

• The scientific community is divided over proposals to impose stricter immigration limits on people with scientific and technical skills.

• The Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP) was established in 2004, offering supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents. OPM does not review disputed claims, and enrollees are responsible for 100% of the premiums.

• Eligible individuals can enroll in FEDVIP during the standard open season for FEHB plans or following a qualifying life event. There are four nationwide dental plans, three regional plans, and three vision plans, with varying premiums based on plan, family members, and residency (for dental plans only).

• Active employees pay FEDVIP premiums on a pre-tax basis, but annuitants, survivor annuitants, or compensationers do not have this option. There are no preexisting condition exclusions, but waiting periods for orthodontia apply. Enrollees pay less out-of-pocket costs using in-network services.

• FEDVIP enrollees can choose self-only, self +1, or family plans, and are not required to enroll in both dental and vision plans. Premiums vary by plan and geographic area, and individuals can enroll in a Flexible Spending Account (FSA) to cover any qualified unmet medical expenses.

• When comparing FEDVIP plans, individuals should consider coverage in their FEHB plan, likelihood of using services covered by the plans, and placing the same dollar amount in an FSA. Under the FEDVIP program, any coverage provided by an individual's FEHB health plan is primary, and the FEDVIP plans are the secondary payers.

• Total private nonfarm employment in the US fell from 2001 to 2003, but has since expanded. Job loss is a significant macroeconomic problem, but the distinction between net job loss and gross job loss is often overlooked in policy debates.

• Gross job loss is the total number of jobs eliminated by contracting firms, while net job loss is the difference between gross job loss and gross job gains. Economists view net job loss as detrimental, but gross job loss as a normal part of a functioning market economy.

• A BLS data series shows that gross job loss and gains are each around 20 times higher than net job loss or gains in any given quarter. The rate of gross job gains and losses has increased over time, indicating a more mobile labor force.

• Small businesses account for a disproportionate share of gross job gains, but also of gross job losses. On net, they account for less than their share of total employment.

• Trade liberalization has not been shown to have a negative effect on net employment, as employment has steadily increased during the post-war period of trade liberalization.

• Gross job loss can translate into net job loss at the local level, and can have social costs such as poverty, psychological problems, and crime.

• Government provision of unemployment insurance can help mitigate the adverse selection and moral hazard problems associated with private insurance markets, but the adequacy and cost of insurance benefits is a policy issue.
</summary>

• Congress has used commemoratives to honor contributions, dramatize virtues, perpetuate remembrance of events, name buildings and scholarships, and establish commemorative observances.
• Commemorative options requiring legislative action include naming federal buildings, creating postage stamps, minting coins, awarding gold medals, authorizing monuments, establishing commissions, and requesting presidential proclamations.
• Nonlegislative options include sending certificates, making floor speeches, and sending flags flown over the Capitol to constituents.
• Initiatives since the 1960s have aimed to reduce the number of commemoratives proposed through legislation due to concerns about excessive legislative time spent on commemorative measures.
• Proposed commissions to recommend appropriate commemorations and amending congressional rules on commemorative legislation have been introduced but not passed.
• The House adopted a new rule in the 104th Congress to prohibit the introduction and consideration of date-specific commemorative legislation, and the rule remains in effect.
• Certificates of recognition, floor speeches, and purchasing American flags are nonlegislative options available to Members of Congress to commemorate individuals, groups, and events.
• The United States has established 11 permanent federal holidays, and legislation is required to create a new federal holiday.
