• Candida albicans or other Candida species colonize the oral cavity of 40-60% of healthy individuals.
• In immune-compromised patients, Candida species can cause various disease manifestations, ranging from localized mild oral lesions to disseminated candidiasis.
• Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic fungal infection in HIV-positive patients, with more than 90% of them developing this infection during the progression of their disease.
• OPC is managed by fluconazole, but prolonged or frequent treatment with azoles can lead to a rise in resistant organisms.
• A shift in Candida species could impact the utility of fluconazole as empiric treatment for candidiasis in HIV/AIDS patients.
• The study aimed to evaluate the forms of OPC and their correlation with CD4+ cell counts in HIV patients.
• The study found that pseudomembranous candidiasis was the most common clinical presentation of OPC, and c. albicans was the most frequent species isolated.
• The distribution of oral lesions based on CD4+ count of HIV-infected patients showed that most oral lesions occurred at CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm.

* The study found that ntapp has several advantages over stapp, including a smaller umbilical skin incision length, shorter operative time, and reduced postoperative pain in the wound region. However, both procedures had similar results in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction.
* The study suggests that the ntapp procedure with smaller caliber trocars can further minimize surgical trauma to the abdominal wall tissue and requires significantly less operating time than the stapp procedure. In uncomplicated hernia repair, ntapp has distinct advantages in the immediate postoperative phase in reduced postoperative wound pain and shorter sick leave.

- Vaspin, a member of the serine protease inhibitor family, is produced in visceral adipose tissue and other organs. Higher plasma vaspin concentrations are found in men with the metabolic syndrome and in patients with type 2 diabetes. However, serum vaspin levels were lower in diabetic patients compared to non-diabetic individuals. In patients with renal insufficiency (RI), serum vaspin levels showed no significant difference between those with and without diabetes.
* Adiponectin, a fat-derived hormone, is associated with obesity-linked diseases and has antidiabetic, antiatherogenic, and antiproliferative effects. Plasma adiponectin levels are reduced in obese humans, particularly those with visceral obesity. In patients with RI, lower BMI may lead to higher adiponectin levels, but in diabetic patients, there is no difference in adiponectin levels between those with and without RI.
* Multiple regression analyses showed that HbA1c levels were independently and significantly associated with vaspin concentration in all subjects. The level of creatinine clearance (CrCL) was found to be independently and significantly associated with adiponectin concentration in all subjects.
* Sex differences were observed in serum vaspin and adiponectin levels, with higher levels found in women than in men. The study also found that the serum vaspin level was lower in diabetic patients than in non-diabetic individuals, which contradicts previous studies. This discrepancy may be due to sex differences and variations in diabetic patients with vascular complications between the two populations.

• Two clinical trials were conducted to test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing.
• A total of 190 ulcers were included in the analyses, and patients received intralesional injections of recombinant human epidermal growth factor (RHEGF) or a placebo.
• The main efficacy variable was granulation tissue development, with a median time to complete closure of 15 weeks.
• Surrogate markers of complete healing were generated, including percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas at the 2nd week and end of treatment (EOT).
• The area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve was calculated for each candidate surrogate variable to evaluate its capacity and quality of discrimination among individuals.
• Cutoff points were generated to maximize both sensitivity and specificity, and the candidate surrogates were then codified and assessed for their association with the final outcome (complete ulcer closure).
• The product coefficient (PC) was used to quantify the contribution of the surrogate on ulcer closure.
• The association with some baseline influencing factors between healing and candidate surrogate variables was estimated using binary logistic regression.
• The most efficient predictor of healing was the granulation tissue covering > 75% of the ulcer area at the EOT, with 79.5% correct classification and a high negative predictive value (93.5%).
• The results suggest that granulation tissue development can be taken into consideration as a surrogate of complete wound closure in advanced DFUs.

</summary>

TAA was also more prevalent in patients with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) compared to those without AAA.
- The study identified several determinants for TAA and AAA, including age, body surface area, diastolic blood pressure, absence or presence of dyslipidemia, smoking history, and presence of AAA or TAA. The study also found that race may influence AAA prevalence, with Asians generally having a lower prevalence compared to Caucasians.
- The study had some limitations, such as the inability to accurately measure aortic root diameter using non-contrast CT and the lack of applicability to females, other ethnicities, or groups with a low risk of cardiovascular disease. Future research should establish distinct screening strategies for TAA and AAA according to risk factors and ethnicity.

- Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of severe vision loss in people aged 55 years and older in developed countries.
* The neovascular form of AMD, involving choroidal neovascularization (CNV) associated with fluid exudation or bleeding, accounts for most cases of AMD-related severe central vision loss.
* Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), has been implicated in the development and progression of AMD.
* Intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment has transformed the management of neovascular AMD, significantly more effective in preventing progressive vision loss and improving visual acuity (VA) than previous alternative treatment modalities.
* Current management of neovascular AMD involves the use of continuing anti-VEGF treatment to control signs of exudation by blocking the growth of abnormal blood vessels to prevent vision loss and potentially improve VA.
* Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents ranibizumab and aflibercept are Health Canada-approved options for the treatment of neovascular AMD.
* Large multicenter clinical trials have demonstrated the efficacy of monthly ranibizumab and intravitreal aflibercept injection every 8 weeks in preventing vision loss and improving VA in patients with neovascular AMD.

</summary>

• The incidence of ipsilateral breast tumor relapse (IBTR) in breast carcinoma patients is less than 6%.
• It is crucial to differentiate between true local recurrence (TR) and new primary tumor (NPT) in IBTR cases.
• Clinical factors, location of the new tumor, staging, and histological subtype should be studied to distinguish TR from NPT.
• A case of a 35-year-old premenopausal woman with IDC in the right breast, treated with surgery, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and hormone therapy, is presented.
• Four years after the initial diagnosis, the patient noticed periareolar thickening in the same breast, and a new IDC diagnosis was confirmed (inflammatory breast cancer).
• The new tumor was ER and PR negative but HER2 positive, in contrast to the first tumor, which was ER and PR positive and HER2 negative.
• The patient received a weekly schedule of paclitaxel, carboplatin, and trastuzumab, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and trastuzumab monotherapy.
• After 4 years and 8 months of follow-up after the last surgery, the patient remains in complete clinical remission.
• IBTR can be TR or NPT, with different natural histories, prognosis, and implications for therapeutic management.
• The risk of second breast cancer depends on ER status, period of diagnosis, and family history of breast and/or ovarian cancer.

</summary>

* The SAP-1 device is a direct endometrial sampler designed for minimal pain during sampling, and it has been found to provide more adequate specimens than d & c or hysteroscopic biopsy.
* Liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology test (ECT) can maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium, and histology is the gold standard for evaluating its accuracy.
* The study found that the accuracy of cytology for detecting endometrial precursor and carcinoma was estimated at 91.7%, sensitivity at 73.6%, specificity at 94.9%, ppv at 71.9%, and npv at 95.3%.
* The sap-1 sampler combined with SurePath preparation may become a reliable method for screening endometrial carcinoma and its precursor, especially in postmenopausal and asymptomatic women.
* The use of this screening procedure in high-risk factor women could avoid unnecessary d & c and enable early detection and management of asymptomatic women with the precursor.

- Breathing process is essential for human survival, and it begins at the upper airway and culminates in gas exchange inside the alveoli.
* Ideal breathing conditions include warmed, moistened, and filtered air, which is achieved when breathing begins through the nose.
* Mouth breathing in childhood, a period of intense facial muscular and skeletal growth, can lead to pathological adaptations of the stomatognathic system.
* Main causes of mouth breathing in childhood include hypertrophy of the pharyngeal and/or palatine tonsil, nasal mucosa and turbinate edema, nasal septal deviation, extended suction habits, and others.
* Morphological adaptations in mouth-breathing children occur to facilitate the arrival of air to the alveoli, leading to alterations in dental occlusion, mandibular inclination, facial growth pattern, and muscular deharmonization.
* Functional changes in the stomatognathic system are observed through alterations in speech, chewing, and deglutition.
* A multidisciplinary approach is essential in the care of mouth-breathers, including otorhinolaryngologists, odontologists, phonoaudiologists, physiotherapists, pediatricians, and others.
* Accurate diagnosis of the cause of mouth breathing is crucial for effective treatment, and the type of care used in phonoaudiology is determined by the etiology of the altered respiratory mode.
* Most causes of mouth breathing are diagnosed through a disarmed otorhinolaryngologic exam, except for the diagnosis of hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils, which demands complementary exams.
* Nasopharyngoscopy is considered the most reliable exam in the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal obstruction, while cephalometry is a noninvasive exam associated with a lower cost and greater availability, and it contributes to the accurate diagnosis of mouth breathing.

</summary>

• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, characterized by network vascular inflammation, demyelination, and axonal damage. It is a chronic disease causing severe cognitive and physical impairments.

• A study was conducted to evaluate the association between c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene with MS in an Iranian population. The study found that there was no significant association between the genotypes or alleles of the IL-25 gene and MS.

• The study also found that the expression level of IL-25 decreased in MS patients, similar to what has been observed in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients. However, the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene was not associated with MS or IBD.

• Other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene, such as 4076a>a, 3672 t>ta, 3712 g>ga, and 3463c>ca, have been found to be associated with MS in Iranian patients.

• The study suggests that the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene is not associated with MS and can not be considered as a risk factor for MS development. Further studies are needed to evaluate other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene and their association with MS.
</summary>

• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, with the highest incidence rates in Europe and North America.
• Digital mammography (DM) is the most commonly performed procedure for breast cancer detection, and it has been shown to reduce mortality rate by up to 50% in some parts of the world.
• DM is less likely to be lost or damaged and has slightly higher sensitivity than screen-film mammography, but it has limitations in detecting breast cancers in women with dense breast tissue.
• Tomosynthesis, a 3-D procedure, may help solve the problem of overlapping tissue in 2-D conventional mammography and improve tumor detection in women with dense breast tissue.
• The use of intravascular contrast material with DM has the potential to enhance tumor detection by taking advantage of malignant neovascularity.
• DM has been shown to reduce radiation doses by 40%-60% compared to screen-film mammography, and a specific digital system using slot scanning with a photon-counting detector has shown the lowest mean glandular dose in clinical screening settings in Europe.
• False positives and missed lesions are a concern in mammography, and women with dense breast tissue have an increased risk of breast cancer, either detected by screening or as interval cancer.

</summary>

* Only a few cases of biopsy-proven vidian nerve schwannomas have been reported in the literature.

• Axillary lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor in breast carcinoma, and worsens with increasing number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• The number of metastatic lymph nodes depends on the number of removed lymph nodes, and it is difficult to reliably assess the axillary lymph node status without removing sufficient numbers of lymph nodes.
• Recent studies suggest that the lymph node ratio (LNR) provides more useful prognostic information compared to nodal disease classification based on the number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• The LNR threshold value varies in different studies, and analysis was mostly made in all lymph node-positive patients, without subdivision in n1, n2, and n3 disease groups.
• In patients with n1 disease, a separate LNR threshold value may be useful to identify high-risk patients.
• Axillary radiotherapy is recommended for patients with a LNR of 0.40 or above in the group with 1-3 metastatic lymph nodes and for patients with a LNR of 0.50 or above in the group with 4 or more metastatic lymph nodes.
• The study evaluates the prognostic significance of the number of removed and metastatic lymph nodes and LNR in breast carcinoma patients with 13 axillary metastatic lymph nodes.

- Posterior transpedicular pedicle screw fixation is commonly used for managing unstable spines, often caused by trauma or burst fractures.
* Transpedicular short-segment fixation, using pedicle screws one vertebra above and below the fracture, is beneficial for correcting kyphotic deformity, providing stability, and enabling early mobilization.
* However, this approach can lead to loss of reduction and instrumentation failure in some cases.
* Adding pedicle screws (intermediate screws) at the fractured vertebra can improve the biomechanical stability of the construct.
* A calf experimental model was used to compare the stiffness of short-segment pedicle fixation with either monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws placed at the level of the fracture.
* The study found that the addition of intermediate screws provided a smaller range of motion (ROM) in flexion, extension, lateral bending, and torsion for both mps and pps groups, indicating enhanced stability.
* The short-segment transpedicular fixation group with intermediate screws had significantly increased stiffness compared to the intact spine in both mpsi and ppsi groups.

- The nasopharyngeal bursa originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut, and can develop into a Tornwaldt's cyst or crust type bursitis if obstructed or if crusts adhere to the orifice.
- The crust type of bursitis can cause an offensive smell and unpleasant taste, and may be difficult to diagnose due to a lack of symptoms.
- The cystic type of bursitis is more common and should be considered in the differential diagnosis of nasopharyngeal abscesses and cysts.
- Symptoms of nasopharyngeal bursitis can include those of a space-occupying lesion or rhinitis, and may include headaches and occipital pain.
- The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults, and can appear at any age.
- A combined endoscopic nasal and transoral approach with electrocauterization can be an effective treatment for both the cystic and crust type of bursitis.
- Proper endoscopic examination and differentiation from nasopharyngeal carcinoma is important for diagnosis and treatment.

• Dermoscopy is a noninvasive diagnostic technique that can improve diagnostic sensitivity by 10-30% but may lower accuracy in inexperienced dermatologists.
• Several scoring systems and algorithms have been proposed to improve diagnostic performance, but within- and between-observer concordance is low.
• In the last two decades, there has been growing interest in automated analysis of digitized images obtained by dermoscopy techniques to differentiate early melanoma from benign skin lesions.
• Computational intelligence methods can help physicians and dermatologists in faster data processing for better and more reliable diagnoses.
• Various border detection, feature extraction, selection, and classification algorithms have been used in automated diagnostic systems for melanoma diagnosis.
• More research is needed to identify and reduce uncertainties in automatic decision support systems to improve diagnosis accuracy.
• A comprehensive up-to-date review of automatic diagnostic models for skin lesions is not available, and a detailed analysis of feature extraction and selection algorithms is needed.
• Performance evaluation measures and model validation details are essential for analyzing various algorithms/models and concluding comments.

<summary>

• Non-native biological invasions have caused significant harm to ecosystems for centuries, such as the Phylloxera destroying grapevines in Europe and chestnut blight in North America.
• Charles Elton's book on invasions in 1957 did not spark widespread research or policy response, but an international project in the mid-1980s led to increased research on the topic.
• Research has shown that non-native invaders can affect ecosystems at the population, community, and ecosystem levels, causing changes in nutrient cycles and other processes.
• Molecular genetic research has revealed that hybridization and introgression between native and non-native species is more common than previously thought, leading to evolutionary changes in native species.
• Introduced species can also facilitate the establishment or impact of other non-native species, leading to "invasional meltdown."
• Critics of invasion biology argue that the problem is overblown, that introduced species can increase native biodiversity, and that the antipathy toward introduced species is xenophobic.
• However, many introduced species do cause harm, and it is not possible to determine the impact of all non-native species due to a lack of research.
• Ecosystem impacts of non-native species can be subtle and take time to manifest, making it important to act before an impact is evident.
• Risk assessment tools have been developed to prevent some planned introductions and prioritize eradication or containment efforts for recently introduced species.
• Biosecurity measures, early detection, and rapid response can be effective in preventing or mitigating the impacts of non-native species, and eradication efforts have been successful in some cases.

</summary>

- The global population is aging, and this trend is expected to continue, with aging being a decreased ability to resist cellular stresses or insults. Aging is a major cardiovascular risk factor, predisposing individuals to conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia.
* The endothelium, which forms a monolayer lining blood vessels, has a primary role in adjusting vascular function. Alterations in the control of endothelial processes often lead to atherosclerosis and other vascular disorders. Endothelial dysfunction is defined as functional alterations in endothelial physiology, characterized by a reduction of vasodilator substance output and augmentation in endothelium-derived contracting factors.
* Oxidative stress, an imbalance between the production of oxidizing agents and opposing antioxidant systems, interferes with endothelial function by reducing nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability. This reduction is due to the rapid inactivation of NO by superoxide anions produced in the aging vascular wall. Oxidative stress also causes alterations in biomolecules, DNA breakage, and decreased NO bioavailability, leading to impaired relaxation and inhibition of the antiproliferative effects of NO.
* Exercise has been shown to improve endothelial function, and vitamin C can restore the impaired vasodilatory response to acetylcholine in older subjects with oxidative stress-induced endothelial dysfunction. Antioxidant defense mechanisms attenuate during the aging process, making older individuals more susceptible to free radical-induced damage.
* Aging increases the levels of tumor necrosis factor- (TNF-), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and C-reactive protein (CRP), which activate the nuclear factor-B (NF-B) pathway, a critical component of inflammatory processes. NF-B induces the expression of proinflammatory cytokines, adhesion molecules, and enzymes, creating a vicious cycle of inflammation and endothelial dysfunction.
</summary>

- The discovery of electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films of inorganic semiconductors and organic dyes has opened a new synthetic route for photoanode material for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs).
- ESA bypasses the high-temperature sintering needed for nanoparticulate TiO2 electrodes, allowing the use of conductive plastic substrates.
- ZnO structures have been used for the construction of photoanodes using ESA, with minor additions of water-soluble dye molecules impacting crystal growth and crystallographic orientation.
- Porous crystal ZnO thin films have been prepared using ESA, resulting in large surface area and high crystallinity, suitable for efficient electron transport and high incident photon to current conversion efficiency (IPCE) of around 90%.
- The development of a compatible system for fabricating sensitized photocathodes is of interest for DSSC applications.
- A porous p-NiO electrode sensitized with a specially designed dye has achieved 1.3% conversion efficiency in an inverted DSSC structure.
- The electrodeposition of CuSCN, a p-type, wide-bandgap semiconductor, into highly crystallized thin films at low temperature is being explored as a counterpart to ZnO-based hybrid systems.
- Dyes with soft Lewis basic ncs groups have been added to the bath for electrodeposition of CuSCN, resulting in colored thin films with nanostructures indicative of their action as structure-directing agents.
- Rhodamine B (RB), a cationic dye, has also been employed as a structure-directing agent for CuSCN electrodeposition, showing positive results in terms of nanostructure formation and crystallographic orientation changes.
- The recent progress in photocathodic DSSCs presents an opportunity to improve the efficiency of dye-sensitized cathode systems, which can eventually be combined with existing sensitized anodes for realization of a tandem solar cell to achieve high efficiencies in very simple structures.

- Oral health is essential for the overall well-being of individuals, and oral lesions can significantly impact their daily activities and social life.
* The prevalence of oral lesions varies according to socioeconomic factors, medical and dental history, treatment expenditure, and handicap.
* No previous studies have estimated the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in the elderly population in the Indian subcontinent.
* The present study aimed to find the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in 5,100 geriatric patients in India, and the results showed that 64% of the patients had various oral lesions.
* Nicotinic stomatitis and denture stomatitis were the most commonly diagnosed lesions, and the hard palate was the most commonly affected site.
* The prevalence of mucosal changes was higher in older patients than in the younger population, and the use of prostheses or their condition can determine the number of oral lesions present in elderly individuals.

• Approximately 10-15% of the adult population has gallstones, with 1 million new patients diagnosed annually, making cholelithiasis the most costly digestive disease at an estimated annual cost of over $5 billion.
• A National Institute of Health conference in 1992 concluded that laparoscopic cholecystectomy offers substantial advantages over traditional open cholecystectomy with no increase in morbidity or mortality, resulting in equal or slightly lower treatment costs and substantial savings due to reduced disability period.
• A retrospective review of 70 cholecystectomy patients showed that the average charge for converted laparoscopic cholecystectomies was $19,922, while that of open cholecystectomies was $13,042 (p<0.01). The amount attributed to laparoscopy was $6,880.
• Decision tree analysis showed that open cholecystectomy was more cost-effective, but if charges could be reduced to certain levels, depending on the conversion rate, laparoscopic cholecystectomy would become cost-effective.
• Sensitivity analysis showed that a reduction in charges and conversion rate is necessary to make laparoscopic cholecystectomy cost-effective.
• Healthcare providers should evaluate charge data and conversion rates for each hospital before contracting for medical services and should use this information to become cost-efficient in performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

• The study found that partial remission (PR) or "honeymoon period" in type 1 diabetes patients is characterized by a reduction in daily insulin requirements and improved glycemic control, but the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. The new definition of PR is based on insulin-dose-adjusted HbA1c (IDAA1c) levels, which has shown a strong correlation with stimulated C-peptide levels.

• The study identified several factors associated with PR, including younger age at diagnosis, absence of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) at diagnosis, and lower HbA1c levels at diagnosis. The duration of PR was significantly shorter in patients with two positive anti-GAD65 and anti-IA2 antibodies at diagnosis. Additionally, higher baseline C-peptide concentrations were observed in both girls and boys entering PR compared to patients without PR.

• The study found no correlation between PR duration or HbA1c+2y levels with occurrence of severe hypoglycemia or diabetes-related complications. The overall occurrence of PR was 56.2% and the mean PR duration was 9.2 months, which was comparable to other studies. The study did not find gender differences in PR rates, but young children had similar PR rates compared to older children.

- Subclinical hypothyroidism (SCH) is a common disorder characterized by an isolated elevation of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with a normal free thyroxine (FT4) level, often representing early mild thyroid failure.
* The clinical significance and optimal treatment of SCH are controversial, with treatment typically considered for pregnant women, infertile individuals, those with symptoms, or those at high risk of progression to overt hypothyroidism.
* SCH has been associated with adverse cardiovascular outcomes, increased weight, altered blood pressure, worsening lipid levels, and vascular problems.
* A systemic review found that SCH has a major impact on metabolic syndrome components, and high normal TSH levels are associated with an increased prevalence of metabolic syndrome.
* The TRUST study, a multicenter, double-blinded, placebo-controlled randomized trial, aims to assess the effects of thyroid hormone replacement in older adults with SCH, evaluating cardiovascular events, quality of life, muscle function, and cognitive function.
* Understanding the prevalence and risk factors of SCH is crucial for preventing cardiovascular disease and mortality, but the decision to treat or not treat an SCH patient depends on clinical judgment, clinical practice guidelines, and expert opinion until the TRUST study results are published and incorporated into updated clinical recommendations.

- The DREAM trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial designed to determine whether ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay the development of type 2 diabetes in people with IFG or IGT.
- Participants receiving rosiglitazone had a significant increase in insulinogenic index (IGI)/homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance index (HOMA-IR) and a significant decrease in proinsulin (PI)/C-peptide ratio, while those receiving ramipril did not have significant changes in these measures.
- Rosiglitazone significantly increased IGI and reduced PI concentrations over time after adjustment for age and insulin resistance, while ramipril did not significantly affect adjusted IGI or PI concentrations.
- After accounting for baseline -cell function as measured by either IGI or PI in models that adjusted for insulin resistance and other covariates, rosiglitazone significantly reduced the risk of developing diabetes.
- Rosiglitazone, but not ramipril, improved measures of -cell function over time in people with IFG and/or IGT, and the demonstration that an agent that reduces diabetes incidence also improves -cell function invites the hypothesis that measures of change in -cell function in response to therapy are indexes of that therapy's ability to reduce the incidence of diabetes.

• Microbial communities have different abilities in degrading toxins, producing natural products, and growing in certain environments compared to monocultures.
• A complete understanding of microbial metabolism must consider both individual strain properties and the interactions within complex communities.
• Interacting microbial strains share metabolites, such as hydrogen, acetate, amino acids, fixed nitrogen, or glucose, and these interactions can be predicted based on individual strain characteristics.
• A general model of metabolic interaction should account for various metabolites exchanged and the genotypic diversity of the strains involved, without requiring detailed biochemical characterization of each participant.
• Using a model set of E. coli auxotrophs, optimization-based techniques of flux balance analysis have been successful in describing metabolic systems and can be extended to higher-order systems of two strains in co-culture.
• Certain pairs of E. coli auxotrophs complement each other's growth in minimal media by cross-feeding essential metabolites, referred to as synthetic mutualism in trans (SMIT).
• SMIT interactions constitute a class of synthetic genetic interactions, reflecting and elucidating the genetic and metabolic network from which they derive, and can be used to identify biosynthetic modules in the metabolic network.
• The complex emergent phenotype of SMIT growth is governed to a significant extent by the relatively simple stoichiometries of the metabolic reaction network.
